urn:contentItem:5JD9-VJK1-JBHT-D44F-00000-00Nightly Business Report2012-12-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:43ZLexisNexisNightly Business ReportWalthamFULL TEXT

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Good evening everyone. I'm Susie Gharib. The unemployment rate drops to a four year low as U.S. businesses add 146,000 jobs in November. We look behind the numbers.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Good evening. I'm Tom Hudson. We meet the CEOs of three small businesses hiring right now. What they do and why they're looking for help.

GHARIB: And House Speaker Boehner accuses President Obama of wasting another week in the fiscal cliff negotiations.

HUDSON: That and more coming up on a Friday night edition here on NBR.

GHARIB: The job market is proving to be surprisingly resilient. American employers hired 146,000 workers in November, much more than expected. And the unemployment rate fell to 7.7 percent. That's the lowest level since December of 2008. As Erika Miller reports, that wasn't the only surprise in today's report.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Almost no one on Wall Street saw this good news coming. There was every reason to think hiring would be weak last month. After all, many parts of the east coast are still recovering from devastation caused by super storm Sandy.

BRUCE KASMAN, CHIEF ECONOMIST, JPMORGAN: I think the most likely explanation here is that Sandy's impact was significant but was so short- lived that it didn't extend to the sample period of the employment report which was the week that covered November 12.

MILLER: Hiring was also supposed to be weak due to worries about the fiscal cliff. With $600 billion in tax hikes and government spending cuts set to start next year, why aren't more firms postponing hiring decisions?

JULIA CORONADO, CHIEF N. AMERICA ECONOMIST, BNP PARIBAS: What we're hearing from businesses is that it is really hard to actually pull back hiring right now, because they've already fired so many workers, gotten so lean that it's really difficult.

MILLER: But not all the surprises in the report were good. At 7.7 percent, the unemployment rate hit its lowest level since December 2008. But that was mostly due to people giving up their search for work. And there's another disappointing trend, weak wage growth.

KASMAN: What we are not seeing is strong income generation. The slowing in wage gains -- the weak bargaining power of labor comes across in this report.

MILLER: So although the labor market is not getting worse, it's not getting a lot better, either. And there are plenty of risks that could cause businesses to cancel projects, and hiring plans.

CORONADO: Clearly one of the biggest risks is that we don't see a deal on the fiscal cliff or that they drag it out over a number of months and that that really erodes confidence.

MILLER: Against that backdrop, the Federal Reserve is trying to do all it can to help the economy. The central bank is widely expected to announce an extension of its bond buying program when it meets next week. Erika Miller, NBR, New York.

HUDSON: With the fiscal cliff about three weeks away tonight, Washington has not made much progress to avoid it. At least that was the assessment today from one of those directly involved in the talks, House Speaker John Boehner. The top Republican accused President Obama of quote, slow walking the economy to the edge of the cliff. He repeated his call for the president to send to Congress a plan that can pass both houses. Tax rates are still the major sticking point. The president wants to raise them for America's highest earners; House Republicans strongly oppose.

REP. JOHN BOEHNER, HOUSE SPEAKER: Instead of reforming the tax code and cutting spending, the president wants to raise tax rates. But even if the president got the tax rate hike that he wanted, understand that we would continue to see trillion dollar deficits for as far as the eye can see. Washington's got a spending problem, not a revenue problem.

HUDSON: Congress and the president now have about 24 days to reach a deal before the fiscal cliff's tax hikes and spending cuts take effect.

GHARIB: Mark Zandi says bad things will happen to the economy pretty fast if lawmakers don't settle the fiscal cliff issue. He's chief economist of Moody's (NYSE:MCO) Analytics. So Mark, falling off the fiscal cliff means bad things. How bad?

MARK ZANDI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY'S ANALYTICS: It could be quite bad, Susie. I don't think it's cataclysmic if we get into January and we haven't settled this, but if House makers haven't nailed this down by early February, I think stock investors, bond investors will start to get very, very nervous, start selling, risky businesses pull back and by the end of February when we start approaching the ceiling for the debt limit, I think we'll be back in recession. It will be a fairly severe recession. So policy makers have a few weeks but not much more than that. They have to get this together.

GHARIB: Some people are saying that today's jobs report is very encouraging and that you can look at this as a way that maybe the economy can handle some tough belt tightening because things are looking a little bit better. How do you think the various parties, Republican and Democrats will handle this jobs report in their fiscal cliff negotiations?

ZANDI: Well, you know, you're right. Some folks look at this and say the economy's strong enough. It should be able to digest big tax increases, spending cuts. Others look at it and say look we still have a very high unemployment rate, a long way to go to get back to full employment. The economy can't tolerate big tax increases and spending cuts. Like most political debates, the reality is in between. We do need to address our fiscal problem so we do need to go through some spending cuts and we also need some tax revenue increases. But we have to phase it in over time, otherwise the economy will choke on that. We can't have too much restraint too quickly. So we have to phase this in, smooth it in to make it palpable for the economy.

GHARIB: But until that happens, there is a lot of anxiety in the labor market. The big fear for many individuals and for investors is that companies are going to start laying off workers. We saw this week that Citigroup (NYSE:C) announced 11,000 job cuts. Is this the beginning of a trend, Mark?

ZANDI: No, Susie, I don't think so. I think if Washington can reasonably address the fiscal issues and I'm still confident that they will ultimately get it together. There will be a fair amount of brinkmanship but at the end of the day, they'll get it together. If they're able to do that when we get into next spring, I do think we're going to be in much better shape. Businesses are going to get their groove back. Certainly investors are going to be very happy about that. By this time next year, I think we should see a much better job market because the housing market, which is already starting to turn should be in full swing. So no, I don't think businesses are going to pull back. The only reason they would is if Washington completely botches this. At this point I don't think that's going to happen.

GHARIB: How do you think the Federal Reserve is going to read and factor in today's jobs report? They're meeting on Tuesday as you know. Do you think it's going to trigger any new response from the Fed?

ZANDI: Well, as you know the Fed's on high alert. They've got their foot to the accelerator. They're now using open-ended quantitative easing, buying long-term bonds and they're going to up the ante I think at the next meeting in the coming week. Operation Twist ends and they're going to start rolling that into this quantitative even process. So a lot of bond purchases. I think they're going to continue to do that until unemployment is moving definitively lower and is much lower than it is today. And most importantly, they're going to wait and see how these things go in Washington. They're very nervous that policy makers aren't going to get this right. So as long as Washington's dithering I think the Fed's going to be on high alert.

GHARIB: Absolutely. Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke has been talking about this for a while now. Thanks a lot Mark, great talking about you. We've been speaking with Mark Zandi, Moody's Analytics.

HUDSON: Still ahead tonight, slow job growth does not discourage tonight's "Market Monitor." Mark Luschini of Janney Montgomery Scott tells us why.

The slow job growth we saw in November, growth but slow, didn't lead to a lot of consumer cheer as December began. The Reuters-University of Michigan consumer sentiment survey fell early this month to its lowest level we've seen since August. So you add all this up here, the Dow Industrials rose 81 points, the NASDAQ was down 11 with some further losses in Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) stock, the S&P 500 up four points. A mixed week for the major indices, the Dow Industrials, which does not include Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), gained 1 percent for the week. With Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), the NASDAQ fell 1.1 percent. And the S&P 500 eked out a 0.01 of 1 percent gain since last Friday.

GHARIB: One hundred of the small businesses behind the job growth that we're seeing were honored last night in Washington with the "Inc" magazine's "hire power" awards. The businesses span the country and cross an array of sectors. Sylvia Hall met with three of the winners to talk about their businesses and the one thing that they have in common: success.

SYLVIA HALL, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: They work in different states and in completely different fields. But together, these CEOs have added more than 1,500 jobs to the nation's economy over the past three years. This is Mike Derheim, who heads a Minnesota tech firm; Sharon Virts Mozer, whose Virginia-based company runs administration for the Federal government and Karl Schledwitz of Memphis, who's turned jerky and hot dogs into opportunity. (INAUDIBLE) seems to be kind of a mature business. How do you find growth there?

KARL SCHLEDWITZ, CEO, MONOGRAM FOOD SOLUTIONS: The actual space is growing. There are meat snacks, beef jerky really started growing with the Atkins diet craze and it's probably quadrupled in the last two years. We've been able to grow by buying under utilized manufacturing facilities and centralizing the back office and putting robust sales operation together filling up the plants. And that creates employment and creates more profitability. It's no different than an office building or a shopping center. If it's half empty, it doesn't do very well cash flow wise, but you take that same exact building and fill it up and it cash flows.

HALL: You work with the Federal government. Again, not exactly what one would consider a growth market. How have you been able to find growth?

SHARON VIRTS MOZER, PRESIDENT, FCI FEDERAL: We found that the demand is going up just based on how the economy's going and the fact that people want to be here in the U.S. We've also found growth through our process and our process takes what I call collaborative work forces and puts them through a methodology in a training program that allows them to accomplish great things.

HALL: Tell me just a little bit about this process.

VIRTS MOZER: We hire typically high school graduates. And we bring them in and we assess their skills and their training and what they have to offer. We put them through a training program to train them towards a particular task or a particular set of tasks.

HALL: One hundred nerds in 100 days. Where did you get to the point where you were on this nerd drive? How did you get here and how is the drive going?

MIKE DERHEIM, CEO, THE NERDERY: We started in November with our 100 nerds and 100 days program and just modeled actually very closely after a PBS telethon member drive. And the deal is that if you were known to us and you get an interview we send you a hundred bucks. If we end up hiring the person we send you another 400 bucks and we're trying to get to a hundred nerds in as many days. As of right now, I think now we've had about 900 applications submitted and we've hired 19 people.

HALL: What's the challenge for you specifically in hiring the people?

DERHEIM: The last I checked the unemployment rate for people in IT, for people that I'm looking for was something like half of the national average. So above all there just aren't enough people who are out there looking for jobs.

HALL: I just wanted to open it up and ask if hiring is a challenge --

VIRTS MOZER: (INAUDIBLE) associated with it and as a result credit issues come up. So finding folks that have the right attitude with good credit particularly since we have a market or a set of work force that often times they are suffering in a poor economy and they do need those jobs but they have credit issues. That's our biggest challenge but for the most part, we have no problems in recruiting this particular market with unemployment as high as it's been.

DERHEIM: I wish we had that problem. We're exactly the opposite. We're struggling all the time to figure out new ways to get more applications in the door. Just a different worker I guess but it's different.

HALL: I wanted to go around and ask this about your growth prospects for the next year.

SCHLEDWITZ: We hope to have more acquisitions this year and continue to add to the plants that we're operating in. So I don't, without an acquisition, it would be 10-15 percent growth.

VIRTS MOZER: We're looking to grow by at least 500 if not 600 jobs by the end of 2013.

DERHEIM: We are planning 25 percent a year revenue growth for 2013. So we're definitely planning continuing to grow aggressively and organically.

HALL: Thank you all so much and congratulations on your awards.

GHARIB: Calling it a robust investment in the region, the White House today said President Obama would ask Congress for more than $60 billion in aid for states impacted by hurricane Sandy. Still that was less than the $82 billion the states wanted for rebuilding. Millions of homeowners and businesses that were in the path of hurricane Sandy are now waiting for checks as the long rebuilding effort begins. Ruben Ramirez spent a day with an insurance claim adjuster touring one of the hardest hit areas.

RUBEN RAMIREZ, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: It's the calm after the storm, empty streets, houses ripped from foundations, boats sandwiched between homes, remnants of the famous Jersey shore boardwalk.

KARL NEW, CLAIMS ADJUSTER, AMERICAN MODERN: What makes this storm different was the large amounts of sand that it brought with it. So the sand and the surge itself, it moved houses just like Katrina did, but it just the sand is bad.

RAMIREZ: Karl New is one of about 30 claims adjusters American Modern Insurance dispatched to New Jersey, New York and Connecticut. For the barrier island off the coast of New Jersey, it was north of the eye of the storm but think of it like a windmill spinning counter-clockwise.

NEW: Seaside was hit with a 37-foot wall wave so that's a pretty big wall that was coming in so you're talking water that's higher than that building. that's crashing in here and causing this much - and the force. It's bringing sand. It's bringing all that water in.

RAMIREZ: It took a month before insurance adjusters were allowed on the island to assess the damage. New inspected this property earlier this week.

NEW: The "L" shape all the way up top, everything is sagging down from the weight of the sand that was pushing it and the water that was pushing it out. It pushed somebody's shed completely right into his house. He got 5 1/2 feet of water in his house so everything on the first floor needs to be completely gutted and taken out.

RAMIREZ: John Marchetti's house sits just two doors down closer to the beach.

JOHN MARCHETTI, HOMEOWNER: I do have flood insurance (INAUDIBLE) and flood. Obviously everything that you see here is from the bottom. It's from the flood.

RAMIREZ: Marchetti's insurer, NJM will take a loss of more than $300 million from Sandy, four times what it paid out from Irene last year. It's the largest loss in the company's history. Industry estimates put the total amount of damage from super storm Sandy at $50 billion. Insurance companies are expected to pick up about $10-$20 billion of that putting super storm Sandy at the top of the list and ahead of hurricanes Ivan, Ike and Irene. Monday we will look at why rebuilding from Sandy is so expensive thanks to where she came ashore. Ruben Ramirez, Seaside Heights, New Jersey.

GHARIB: Back here on Wall Street, Tom, some interesting revolutions from Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) today saying that it got a Wells notice, is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But behind it is a very interesting debate going on. The reason for the investigation is that the CEO Reid Hastings had posted some information on his Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) page about developments at the company and the SEC said you didn't disclose this properly. It should have been a press release. It should have been a filing with the SEC and it raises whole new questions about social media and fair disclosure.

HUDSON: This is all about how technology is changing and regulations have such a hard time Susie keeping up with it. We've see it with high frequency trading for instance and now we're seeing with how companies disseminate information using social media getting it out arguably to more people faster than what a traditional press release or SEC filing. So we'll have to see how this one plays out. That stock by the way Susie didn't move much today on the notice although we did have plenty of other movement. Let's get going with our "Market Focus" here. As we saw the influence of Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) that it can have on the broad market really continue today with the major indices closing mix. The jobs data helped the S&P 500 start in the green but the early gains disappeared as Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) shares sank. The index climbed into positive in the afternoon and was able to finish up a 0.03 of a percent. Trading volume slowed, 605 million on the big board, 1.6 billion shares on the NASDAQ.

The materials and financials sectors gained 0.08 of a percent. The energy sector up 0.07 of a percent. Technology was the big drag, thanks once again to Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), AAPL. Over the past week here it is, gone from almost $600 per share down to $533. That's down about 9 percent. Looking at it longer term in the last year, the sell-off with Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) now about $8 above that mid-November low. Several theories behind the stock drop: profit taking, disappointment over no special dividend and more fundamental concerns about Apple's business growth.

Two other big tech stocks under pressure. Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) falling 1 percent, just pennies tonight above its low for the year. Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO) Systems falling 0.07 of 1 percent. The firm repeated today its previous earnings growth forecast.

Big banks, they were on the upswing though with further improvement in the job market, and ahead of next week's Federal Reserve meeting with expectations building for the possibility of more economic help. JPMorgan (NYSE:JPM) jumped 2.6 percent, its highest price since early November. Bank of America (NYSE:BAC) added another 1.8 percent. That's an 18-month high for shares of B of A.

A big global energy deal one step closer to reality tonight. Late today Canada OK'd the buyout of Nexen (NYSE:NXY) Energy by Chinese energy giant C-NOOC. It's a $15.3 billion deal, representing another foreign expansion by a Chinese energy company. Canada's ministry of industry said C-NOOC agreed to quote, free market principles. The buyout offer for Nexen (NYSE:NXY) came back in July. In today's regular session, the stock was heavily traded falling 6.6 percent. But after the Canadian OK, they jumped more than 14.5 percent in extended hours trading, around $27 per share. U.S. and British regulators still have to approve the deal.

Two years ago Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) offered $6 billion to buy daily deal website Groupon (NASDAQ:GRPN) before it went public. Groupon's market value is half that tonight. Bloomberg reports there's new take-over speculation. By whom we don't know. The stock though jumped 23 percent. Volume doubled. Some of the buying could also be from traders who sold short the stock to profit as it was falling.

Four of the top five most actively traded exchange-traded products were higher. The lone hold-out the NASDAQ 100 tracking fund, which does include Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) after all. The fund was down 0.06 of 1 percent today. And that is tonight's "Market Focus."

Job growth is one reason tonight's "Market Monitor" thinks the economy will pick up speed next year and so will stocks. Mark Luschini back with us, chief investment strategist at Janney Montgomery Scott. Always great to see you Mark. So the job market that we saw today improving in the last month but still slow. Do you think it's going to pick up the pace of that improvement next year and why?

MARK LUSCHINI, CHIEF INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, JANNEY MONTGOMERY SCOTT: Well we do, Tom. The fact of the matter is we've been seeing steady if unspectacular job growth for the better part of 2012, job growth averaging roughly 150,000 or so a month. We think on the back of an up tick on several factors here that we're looking forward to improve in 2013, we could see a modicum of an up tick in job growth.

HUDSON: Among those other improvements you see consumers paying down debt as beneficial to the economy. Doesn't that lead to less demand, less consumer spending?

LUSCHINI: We think it's bringing up their balance sheet.

HUDSON: Which is a good thing.

LUSCHINI: It is a good thing. All this (ph) leads to a much healthier foundation upon which consumption can be built which is all important in the economy.

HUDSON: Where are we in that de-leveraging cycle do you think, closer to the end?

LUSCHINI: I think it's advanced. I think it's probably a 2015-16 phenomena before we get trend but nonetheless, well off the peak in 2006.

HUDSON: Businesses meantime are not necessarily de-leveraging. They don't necessarily have to. They have a lot of cash out there but they're not spending it. You think they're going to less loose some of that cash. We've heard so much uncertainty about the fiscal cliff and companies holding back. How are those two related?

LUSCHINI: I think the fiscal cliff ultimately is going to be rendered into a fiscal slow. Between now and then the uncertainty is really paralyzing CEOs and companies from big to small. You can see it in the core capital goods orders which have basically fallen off in the last two quarters indicative of holding that business investment and hiring back which we think will change once we have some certainty brought into that equation.

HUDSON: Finally housing which has shown remarkable stability here, an uptick in several markets but there's talk about limiting mortgage deductions with the fiscal cliff negotiations sometime next year. Couldn't that impact the recovery?

LUSCHINI: It could. Obviously it might be relegated to more affluent households in terms of the ability to do a deduction either in full or part. But at the end of the day there's still a large swath of household formation that is occurring that's going to drive I think perspective homeowners into the market regardless.

HUDSON: Let's get to the pics here. You do like housing stocks with the home builders ETF. What do you anticipate? They've had a nice run already.

LUSCHINI: They've been terrific.

HUDSON: Put new money to work?

LUSCHINI: We turned bullish about a year ago and they've doubled or better and yes we would. They may be subject to profit taking but nonetheless we still think we're in the early innings of the house recovery.

HUDSON: You also like technology. Is this a play on your business investment expectations for next year?

LUSCHINI: It is, if business wallets open up we expect the destination for some of that money to go towards more productivity enhancing tools and they've been under investing in technology now for several years.

HUDSON: What about that transition from the PC to tablets and smart phones? Does that concern you at all about traditional technology terms firms?

LUSCHINI: It does a little bit. Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) is intriguing and then really the sweet spot of that. The fact of the matter is though it's an interesting company that is trying to make itself into more of a tablet or a smart phone oriented company. In the meantime they get paid an enormous dividend yield to wait.

HUDSON: Speaking of which, I know you like dividend stocks. The last time we spoke to you July 6, you liked Conoco Phillips and Johnson & Johnson (NYSE:JNJ). Both of them in terms of just the stock price appreciation up by single digits percentage terms. You still like them.

LUSCHINI: Very much so. Battleship companies good places to be in, in health care and energy and again a very handsome coupon (ph) which is think is going to matter to total return.

HUDSON: Do you own everything that we mentioned tonight?

LUSCHINI: We do.

HUDSON: Our Friday "Market Monitor" guest Mark Luschini. He's with Janney Montgomery Scott.

LUSCHINI: Thanks Tom.

GHARIB: And it's often said that in life, it's not the destination that counts, but the journey. This week Lou's been thinking about journeys and their not so straight lines. Here's author and educator, Lou Heckler.

LOU HECKLER: How many of you are now doing what you thought you'd be doing when you first went to work? I'll guess maybe about 25 percent. I was reminded of this recently when I spoke to a group of dentists about leadership. We talked about how they got into dentistry because they liked working with their hands, they liked helping people. And now? Now, they also negotiate building leases and manage staffs and cope with shrinking reimbursements and the soft economy. My first job as a manager involved leading 17 people in a television news department.

One day, one of my old college friends surprised me by asking: how does it feel to be out of the news business? I only later realized he meant that all of us who have the privilege of leading others soon realize that leading is our job. That once-straight line we visualized where our skills were needed has zigs and zags in it. The skills we now need to learn and hone and practice have changed. It's a wonderful honor to be at the top of an organization, but that old concept of straight to the top, that's not how it is. Not by a long shot. I'm Lou Heckler.

GHARIB: And finally, we want to let all of you know that we've posted an extended version of our conversation with NBR founding anchor Paul Kangas from yesterday. It's on the web at nbr.com and have a great weekend everyone and Tom, it was great seeing you yesterday as well.

HUDSON: Great to have you in south Florida Susie with Paul as well, a lot more viewer questions on that extended video at nbr.com. Have a great weekend and we'll see you back here nest week.

END

urn:contentItem:552J-VXJ1-JC11-926V-00000-00Nightly Business Report2012-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:43ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT6:30 PM ESTGlenn Tongue, James RogersBUSINESS022701cb.118Nightly Business ReportTom Hudson, Susie Gharib, Suzanne Pratt, Darren Gersh

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Oil prices slip on fresh worries about demand and the global economy. But, traders say there`s no stopping prices at the pump.

ANTHONY GRISANTI, PRESIDENT, GRZ ENERGY: I think wholesale wise, you`re going to see $5 gas in a lot of areas of the country, especially the coasts.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: And this man is a big investor in Berkshire Hathaway stock. We took his pulse after Warren Buffett released his annual letter to shareholders. It`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Monday, February 27.

GHARIB: Good evening, everyone. A pullback in oil prices today after days of spurting higher. There are still worries about Iran and supply disruptions, but Tom, those were overshadowed by concerns that the world economy is slowing.

HUDSON: At least for today Susie, the risk of higher prices still a concern though over the weekend at a meeting of the world finance ministers. Get you updated on today`s trading in New York, crude oil futures lost $1.21 to close at $108.56 per barrel. Still, U.S. oil prices are up 10 percent this year.

GHARIB: Those high prices have pushed energy stocks up as well. And, as Suzanne Pratt reports, there could still be time for investors to take advantage of the big move higher in big oil stocks.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: No matter where you pump, gas prices have been heading higher. And, that`s bad news for consumers and perhaps the whole economy and its fragile recovery. But, it`s been good news for big oil companies or super majors and their shareholders. So far this year, a closely watched energy sector ETF is up 10 percent moving almost in lock step with the rise in oil and gas prices. The question is whether oil stocks have more room to run. The answer depends on what happens here at the pump. Many factors affect oil company profits, including costs and environmental disasters. But, a big rise in prices plays the biggest role. One energy expert says what`s most important is that crude oil prices remain close to or above $100 a barrel.

ELIECER PALACIOS, ENERGY SECTOR SPECIALIST, MAXIM GROUP: A deep water well costs about $50 a barrel, $75 depending where you are. So, if you can sell your oil at $100 plus, it`s very positive for any of these companies.

PRATT: So, where are oil prices headed next? Energy trader Anthony Grisanti says that`s easy: higher.

ANTHONY GRISANTI, PRESIDENT, GRZ ENERGY: Number one you have the threat from Iran that`s being held over this market and number two, as far as refineries closing, you`ve had three of them close on the east coast. You`ve had a couple go down on the west coast. You`ve had some in Europe being shut down and these are shutdowns that are going to be permanent.

PRATT: Others aren`t so certain energy prices will continue to climb north. They believe geopolitical tensions will be less of a support for the market and then there`s the demand concern. Higher prices at the pump usually means people buy less gas, which in turn pushes prices lower. Still, others say one more reason to consider buying big oil shares these days is their dividends. On average they pay about 3 to 4 percent and those payouts come no matter what happens to oil prices. Suzanne Pratt, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: A potential new source for imported oil into the U.S. is trying again. Back in January, the Obama administration blocked Trans- Canada`s Keystone XL pipeline over environmental concerns. But the company today said it will start building the southern leg of that pipeline, running from the Cushing, Oklahoma oil storage hub to refineries on Texas` Gulf coast. The $2.3 billion project is smaller. It should be up and running by the end of next year. And since it does not cross international borders, it won`t be subject to a full-blown Federal environmental review.

GHARIB: Meanwhile, the trial to decide who should pay for the nation`s worst oil spill was delayed today. The one-week delay allows BP time to continue negotiations with the plaintiffs` steering committee. That committee represents condominium owners, fishermen, hotel and restaurant operators and others who say their livelihoods were damaged by the Deepwater horizon explosion and subsequent oil spill. Still, BP says there`s no guarantee a deal can be reached.

HUDSON: All this energy talk in the background, blue chip stocks once again tested the 13,000 mark on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Once again, the Dow failed to close above that level. Here`s how the day played out for the major indices, the Dow plunging over 100 points actually at the open and then coming back to life on a report that pending home sales showed a jump in the number of sales contracts signed last month. Still, the Dow did end the day down slightly as you saw, down about a point and a half, the NASDAQ rose two, the S&P 500 was up about same amount.

After the closing bell, Greece was officially rated to be in default of its IOUs. S&P cut Greece`s long-term credit rating to selective default. Earlier this month, S&P warned it would make the downgrade if Greece was going to force its lenders to swap their IOUs for new ones, accepting less money. Greece is doing just that and now the selective default rating brings up questions if payments on bond insurance and derivatives will be triggered. Still ahead, tonight`s "Word on the Street" -- cloud. James Rogers of thestreet.com has three cloud computing stock picks looking for bright days.

GHARIB: A lot of talk today about Warren Buffett and succession plans at Berkshire Hathaway where he is chairman and CEO. He gave some clues over the weekend when he released his annual letter to shareholders. Here are the highlights. On the topic of succession, Buffett said one individual has been chosen, but he didn`t identify the person. Buffett, who is 81 years old and his business partner Charlie Munger, 88, have no plans to step down. But Buffett did say the transfer of responsibility will be seamless when the time comes.

Buffett also reported that Berkshire`s fourth quarter profits fell 30 percent and 2011 earnings down 21 percent. But the company`s cash rose to $37 billion. On housing, Buffett said the market remains in a quote depression of its own and he was dead wrong predicting it would recover by now. On the topic of investing, stocks will outperform gold and bonds. And even though investors believe bonds are safe, Buffett says they are quote among the most dangerous of assets.

I turned to Glenn Tongue for some reaction and analysis. He`s managing partner at T2 Partners, where Berkshire Hathaway is its top holding. We began by talking about Buffett`s succession plan.

GLENN TONGUE, MANAGING PARTNER, T2 PARTNERS: I think it`s likely that Mr. Buffett running the company for another five years. However, if the unexpected happens and he`s not running the business tomorrow, it`s very comforting knowing that there`s someone in line to run the business.

GHARIB: But Glenn, why doesn`t Warren Buffett just name his successor? Why the mystery?

TONGUE: I don`t see why naming the individual today is a benefit to the company, to the shareholders. People that work with Berkshire Hathaway, companies that sell their businesses to Warren Buffett and Berkshire Hathaway want to be dealing with him. They don`t want to be dealing with the next in line. They don`t want to be thinking about those issues. When Mr. Buffett is no longer running the company, then someone else will step into that role.

GHARIB: Let`s talk about Berkshire Hathaway the company, how is it doing?

TONGUE: Fantastically well. The five most important operating businesses operated at record levels this year. He stated in the letter that they`re going to be generating $10 billion in profits next year, just an enormously profitable business.

GHARIB: So quarterly profits were down 30 percent for the year, 2011, also down.

TONGUE: If you look at each and every one of the operating businesses, whether it`s the utilities or the railroads or (INAUDIBLE) manufacturing businesses, they were all up year over year. They were all up quarter over quarter in terms of operations. So the underlying businesses are doing terrifically well. There`s some accounting conventions that are required, certain write offs and write downs, that made the earnings go down, but the cash flow of the company certainly went up and the operating performance has never been stronger.

GHARIB: But what Berkshire stock? The A shares have been trading at around $120,000 for two years now. What do you think?

TONGUE: We value Berkshire stock and we think it`s worth about $180,000 per share. We were buying Berkshire stock today very aggressively in the marketplace. It`s got the most powerful balance sheet of any company in America and it`s got earnings power that is growing very, very rapidly.

GHARIB: Would you be that optimistic if tomorrow Warren Buffett were no longer running the company?

TONGUE: When we value Berkshire Hathaway, there`s no element of the Warren Buffett premium that we throw into our valuation. We think if Mr. Buffett left the company, that people would still drink Coca-Cola tomorrow. The trains would still be running the next day and people would be ensuring themselves through Geico. So we value those elements of the business.

GHARIB: What`s your reaction to what Warren Buffett said about bonds as the most dangerous of assets? Do you agree with that?

TONGUE: Yes I agree with it. If you look at the interest rate that we`re getting on bonds today, it`s very, very low and if interest rates -- prevailing interest rates go up, the principal amount of the bonds will go down over time, so you`re going to lose purchasing power by investing in bonds today.

GHARIB: So Berkshire`s cash is now up to $37 billion. Is it time to pay a dividend, even though Buffett is not a fan of them?

TONGUE: I don`t think so. I think Warren Buffett can find better deals with the cash than the shareholders can with the dividends. He finds very unique opportunities like investing in preferred stock in Bank of America. It`s a fantastic deal that was available only to Berkshire Hathaway and only to Warren Buffett.

GHARIB: Glenn, thank you so much, really enjoyed talking with you.

TONGUE: Thank you Susie. I enjoyed it too.

HUDSON: Warren Buffett also today said that he would buy millions of single family homes if he could. 2,500 of them went on sale under a new Federal pilot program. The idea is to sell Fannie Mae-owned homes to private investors who want to use them as rental properties. As Darren Gersh reports, these homes may go fast.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Warren Buffett is not alone. Money-making ideas love company and large investors and private equity types already have hundreds of millions, maybe billions of dollars on hand to buy up foreclosed homes and rent them out. At Carrington Holding, Rick Sharga says the company is ready to buy 30,000 to 40,000 homes.

RICK SHARGA, EXEC. VP, CARRINGTON HOLDING CO.: I think we all agree with Warren Buffett. If we could buy millions of homes, we`d be doing that right now. There is a lot of capital that`s very interested in participating in a program like this.

GERSH: Like this, meaning a pilot program announced by Federal regulators who took charge of the troubled mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac when the companies were placed under government control. The Federal Housing Finance Agency today announced a test sale of 2,500 homes around the country. Focusing on cities from Los Angeles to Las Vegas and much of Florida, places where housing fell hard. But this is a tiny fraction of the 700,000 or so foreclosed homes now on the books of financial institutions. And here`s the problem: Warren Buffett wanna- be`s say they can`t find enough homes to buy now. Some banks may be holding off on selling, believing they can get a higher price. Others may not be carrying foreclosed homes on their books at realistic market prices.

SHARGA: And that could cause a lender or somebody else holding these properties to have to do a significant write down at the point that they execute the sale.

GERSH: As investors prepare to become big landlords, economist Dean Baker hopes regulators will be more creative. He`d like to see renters offered a chance to become old-fashioned American homesteaders.

DEAN BAKER, CO-DIR., CNTR. FOR ECONOMIC & POLICY RSCH.: The basic idea is that you have someone come in and pay some nominal amount to buy it initially and then if they stay there and fix it up and pay their taxes, live in the place for five years, then it`s theirs.

GERSH: With private equity lining up to buy rental properties, critics worry the industry that caused the housing crisis is now preparing to profit from the destruction. But investors argue the bad actors have gone out of business.

SHARGA: It`s a popular sentiment that the same folks who got us into this mess are now going to profit on the way back. Fortunately, it`s not true.

GERSH: While Warren Buffett dreams of buying millions of homes, big investors have more modest hopes. They figure the market for big investors and private equity is about 200,000 foreclosed homes over the next two years. Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

GHARIB: More housing headaches for bank of America. The giant bank was hit with a lawsuit by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development today. It`s charged with discriminating against disabled homebuyers. The agency says B of A put unnecessary and burdensome requirements on disabled borrowers. In two separate states, borrowers complained saying they had to show medical records to prove their disabilities and detail their Social Security income. Bank of America says the cases came down to inconsistencies between Federal Housing Administration lending standards and conventional underwriting standards. And that it followed with stricter Federal standards which require more detail.

With fees rising and customer service falling, more Americans ditched big banks last year and moved their money to small banks and credit unions. JD Power and Associates surveyed 5,000 people who shopped for a new bank or bank account over the past year. Its defection rate for large, regional and midsize banks averaged as high as 11 percent last year, up sharply from 2010. Meanwhile smaller banks and credit unions lost less than 1 percent of their customers. That was far better than the near 9 percent defection rate those small shops saw a year ago. And Tom, surprisingly, bank stocks, big and small led the market higher today.

HUDSON: A lot of folks are putting their money into those bank stocks today, even though we got that news on how the customers have been behaving over the past year or so. Susie, let`s go ahead and take a look at what was going on with tonight`s "Market Focus." Overall a mixed finished for the major stock indices on this Monday. The Dow Industrials as we mentioned earlier unable to stick above that 13,000 level. Stocks were able to bounce back though from the early session selling you can see on the left hand side of the chart, thanks to some encouraging signs in the housing market. Those pending home sales were up. We`ll talk more about those in a second. The Dow did dip into the closing bell though, ending with that small loss.

It was a trio of financial stocks though that were the best performers inside the Dow. JPMorgan and Bank of America each gaining two percent. American Express rallying more than 1.5 percent in the session. In the broad market, financials, yes were the strongest, no doubt about it, but the gains though pretty tame, under 1 percent. Financial discretionary sector was the second best today and even that was up only 0.3 of 1 percent gain, a muted gain for the day.

The jump in pending home sales -- purchases really helped spark some buying in home-related areas of the entire stock market. Pending contracts on those existing homes jumped 2 percent in January, up to their highest level in almost two years, bullishness there in real estate. That news on helped push up shares of Whirlpool to a seven-month high, jumping almost 7 percent. Volume was strong today trading in Whirlpool.

Paint maker Sherwin Williams also moving higher, up to a new high as a matter of fact with a 2 percent rally. Shares are up more than 26 percent in just the past year. Speaking of homes, home supplies retailer Lowe`s turned in earnings a nickel better than estimates. Similar to Home Depot`s quarter that we saw last week, Lowe`s benefited from mild winter weather allowing customers to start on those home improvement projects early. Shares of Lowe`s saw heavier than usual volume, but were up less than 1 percent.

Focus shifted after the close to online travel company priceline.com and the name your own price website continues to see some pretty big growth numbers. Check it out. Wall Street was expecting a big jump in earnings already from a year ago. Priceline did not disappoint. Results were more than $0.30 stronger than estimates. Both international and domestic travel bookings were better than expected. Priceline shares saw little movement during the regular session, but watch these tomorrow. They shot up more than 6 percent in after hour`s action to over $628 per share. If that holds tomorrow, it would be more than a decade high for PCLN.

A big bankruptcy in Japan may mean one less global maker of a commonly used memory chip for computers and that had shares of Micron jumping today here in the U.S. MU, the ticker symbol, jumped almost 7 percent to an eight-month high. El-Pida (ph) Memory in Japan filed for bankruptcy under the weight of some big loans coming due. Micron is the last U.S. space maker of what are called DRAM, dynamic random access memory chips.

While the overall energy sector cooled a bit today as we mentioned, we did see some buying in a giant oil driller as well as a master limited partnership based in nat gas. Driller Transocean rallied 5 percent. It reported a loss last quarter related to the 2010 Gulf of Mexico spill, indicating a possible settlement in that case may be coming. Cheniere Energy Partners meantime, the master limited partnership focused on liquefied natural gas jumped to a new 52-week high, up 12 percent. Private equity firm Blackstone is investing $2 billion to help the firm build a liquefied nat gas plant in Louisiana.

A lot of the commodity market focus has been on energy lately, who can blame them. But today soybeans really took the lead. Beans in the teens, you heard that phrase, the old saying at the Chicago Board of Trade and we`re there for the first time since last fall at least for the May futures contract. Beans jumping above $13 a bushel for the first time in five months. The market thinks that the South American harvest will be disappointing, while global demand for beans continues growing. And that is tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: And record help for the nation`s farmers in the form of crop insurance. U.S. farmers received $10 billion in crop insurance payments last year and with 5 percent of 2011 claims outstanding, that number could go higher. Drought in the great plains, spring flooding along the Mississippi River and crop-damaging freezes in the south pushed claims higher. The last record was in 2008. That`s when payouts topped $8.5 billion.

HUDSON: The forecast for technology is cloudy like cloud computing. The movement to on-demand software and data storage continues to pick up in a big way. That brings us to tonight`s "Word on the Street" -- cloud. James Rogers back with us now, technology editor at thestreet.com. James, Mr. Editor, nice to see you, congratulations on the new gig.

JAMES ROGERS, TECHNOLOGY EDITOR, THESTREET.COM: Thank you very much.

HUDSON: So tell us how cloud computing is different and how it`s changing?

ROGERS: Well, you know cloud computing has been one of the big textbook words of recent years and it`s a trend that`s really picking up. It`s becoming a mainstream technology. What is it? Basically there`s different forms of cloud. Cloud could be a business that say, accessing servers and storage capacity from a hosting company like Rackspace or it could be a business that`s using specialized software services, someone like salesforce.com where all of these areas are growing.

HUDSON: You mentioned two companies there, but first, EMC. This is kind of the granddaddy in the space, data storage and hardware. Share prices had a sharp rally in the past six weeks or so. What could fuel it higher?

ROGERS: EMC provides a lot of the core infrastructure that`s needed for these cloud service providers, could be things as you say like basic storage hardware or virtualization software from EMC is very, very popular, VMWare subsidiary. It`s got a lot of weapons in its arsenal, a lot of other things, data security, disaster recovery, data analytics and I think because of this bigger picture, it`s really in the sweet spot for the cloud. Cloud and demands for cloud services helped push EMC to record quarterly results recently, kind of continuing a consistent run of (ph) results from this firm. I think that EMC is actually one of tech`s best performers. It may not be the sexiest stock out there, but I think that there`s a lot more upside potential for investors here, particularly with the push towards the cloud.

HUDSON: EMC is kind of the soup to nuts, the old school cloud play here, 90 seconds left and I want to get to the other two. Software side, salesforce.com, CRM the ticker symbol. It`s had a heck of a quarter, has already said it`s got a record order on its books in this current quarter. How can it move higher?

ROGERS: I have salesforce down as one of the big tech rebound stocks for 2012 and I think it`s really starting to live up to that billing. This is a company that is really one of the first cloud trail blazers, and if you look at its resources, what we`re seeing is that salesforce is actually clinching more and more large enterprise deals, also its social enterprise strategy seems to be taking off. Now we`re concerned about this company`s growth potential last year, but I think that maybe we`re seeing a bit overblown. There`s a lot more growth to this firm.

HUDSON: Finally, 30 seconds on Rackspace, RAX the ticker symbol. This is really seen as the pure play in cloud. And the stock price kind of reflects that as the excitement has picked up in the last several weeks.

ROGERS: This is another company that`s come out strong results and like a lot of its competitors like AT&T, Rackspace focuses solely on the cloud, really impressive reputation for customer support and also I spoke to some of the executives there recently and they were telling me that they`ve got a lot of new products planned for this year. And also on the financial side of the company, there`s a great price to earnings ratio so I think that there`s a lot of upside to have there.

HUDSON: A little bit of valuation play there in technology. Can you or do you own any of these stocks, James?

ROGERS: No, none whatsoever.

HUDSON: You can read James` article at the street.com. You can find a link on our website as well. It`s our guest this evening, James Rogers with the street.com.

ROGERS: Thank you, Tom.

GHARIB: As the nation gears up for primaries in Michigan and Arizona tomorrow, tonight`s commentator says there`s something she`d really like to see during this presidential race. She`s Maya Macguineas, president of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.

MAYA MACGUINEAS, PRES., CMTE. FOR A RESPONSIBLE FED. BUDGET: It`s campaign season and with campaigns come lots of promises. Last week, we released a report looking at how the Republican candidates campaign proposals would affect the country`s bottom line and we have also analyzed the president`s budget. Suffice it to say, we are on track for a whole lot of red ink.

So here`s my proposal. Once we get to the general election, we should have a debate focusing solely on fixing the budget. Each candidate would be required to put forth a plan to save $5 trillion over a decade with the full set of details. And it would give us, the voters, a chance to see what it really takes to create a responsible budget. We`d see what it takes if we don`t raise any taxes at all or cut them further as all the Republicans have proposed; and we see how much it would take in tax increases to cover all the new spending the president has proposed while also bringing down the deficit. Better yet, we might see what a more realistic proposal would look like. Maybe the candidates wouldn`t show up, maybe they would try to use funny numbers. But maybe, just maybe it would jumpstart the long overdue national discussion about what it will really take to fix the budget. I`m Maya Macguineas.

GHARIB: And finally tonight, from insider trading to Ponzi scheme, FBI investigations into financial crimes last year led to billions in court-ordered restitution. The Feds say they won more than 3,000 financial crime convictions last year, securing $12 billion in court ordered payouts. In some cases, the government itself was the victim through Medicare fraud. And the FBI leaned on Gordon Gekko himself or the actor who played him in the "Wall Street" movies to help fight financial crime. Michael Douglas stars in a new public service announcement warning investors about deals that are too good to be true.

HUDSON: Here`s what we`re watching for tomorrow. We`ve got some new data coming out, the latest numbers on durable goods orders. We`ll see if that washing machine or couch that you purchased in January is adding to the economy. We`ll also get the latest on home prices, the S&P Case Shiller home price index for December. Then, when it comes to the economy, it`s the economy and politics this fall, no doubt about it and we will take a look at campaign promises versus political realities.

That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Monday evening. Thanks for joining us. It`s February 27th. I`m Tom Hudson. Have a great night Susie.

GHARIB: Tom, hope you have a wonderful evening. I`m Susie Gharib. Thanks for watching everyone. Hope to see all of you again tomorrow night.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Better news out of Greece gives U.S. stocks a better day, but worries persist.

JONATHAN CORPINA: We've had a very successful run-up in our market over the last year and a half, but any headline that comes out of Greece that shows the country has the possibility of defaulting would truly have a global economic effect.

HUDSON: From Greece to Wall Street, we wrap up what's been a rocky week for investors. It's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Friday, June 17.

Good evening and thanks for joining us tonight. Some cautious signs of relief by investors around the world today. There's a rescue plan in the works for Greece. Jittery financial markets stabilized somewhat after Germany agreed to a compromise deal to resolve the economic problems in Greece. U.S. stocks took that news and finished mixed today. The Dow Industrials was able to gain 42 points; the S&P slipped more than seven, rather the NASDAQ slipped more than seven. The S&P 500 gained almost four.

Now here's how things looked for what was a rough week for investors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average added almost 1.5 percent. That snapped a six-week losing streak. The NASDAQ though didn't fare as well, falling 1 percent for the week. The S&P turned positive this week, ending a six-week slide, adding just a fraction. Despite today's market rebound of sorts in America, investors are still worried about Greece. As Suzanne Pratt reports, Americans will be following the Greek drama closely for weeks to come.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Recently Greece has gone from being viewed as a fabulous tourist spot to a thorn in the side of U.S. stock investors. The question now is whether Greece and its financial woes will dictate the direction of the American stock market for the immediate future. NYSE trader Jonathan Corpina says it absolutely will because investors hate uncertainty and Greece's financial outlook is far from certain.

JONATHAN CORPINA: Until we have some stability, any information about a plan or some sort of recovery that's put in place coming out of Europe and Greece at that point then investors will feel much more confident to get back in the market. Looking into today, markets are positive this morning and leading into the afternoon due to the fact that the headlines are coming our of Greece.

PRATT: Market strategist Rick Bensignor agrees positive news out of Greece is just as important for U.S. investors as negative.

RICK BENSIGNOR, MARKET STRATEGIST: If by chance something good out over the weekend, a good headline or something like that, it wouldn't surprise me if the S&P was up 20, 25 points on Monday, the Dow up a couple hundred points. Good news could easily turn the psychology very quickly.

PRATT: Still others say the issue right now for the U.S. stock market is that it's in a bit of an information void. Reporting season for corporate profits is still nearly a month away and lately there's been little major U.S. economic data for investors to chew on. As a result, every twist and turn across the pond with Greece and its weaker neighbors gets extra special attention on U.S. trading floors. And experts say investors should expect Greece and its debt troubles to remain in the headlines for some time.

BENSIGNOR: You can't fix it for good over the weekend. It's too big a problem with too far reaching circumstances. And, it's not just Greece. Greece is just the one in the headlines the most these days. But, there's a likelihood that this stuff spreads to Ireland, Spain and Portugal.

PRATT: One thing many market pros agree on is if Greece defaults on its government debt, it will mean big trouble for U.S. stocks. In fact, some estimate major market averages could quickly lose as much as 15 percent. Suzanne Pratt, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: While Greece's debt woes are grabbing headlines tonight, Italy's problems may be heating up. Late today, Moody's investor service put Italy on review for possible downgrade. Moody's is worried the country won't be able to cut spending enough to reduce its debt.

Back here in the U.S. meantime, watch for slower economic growth. That's what the International Monetary Fund predicts. The global lending agency today said it thinks the U.S. economy will grow 2.5 percent this year, 2.7 percent next year. Both are down from a previous estimate issued just two months ago. The IMF's Jose Vinals says the U.S. and Eurozone nations are playing with fire, unless they take steps to cut their budget deficits immediately.

JOSE VINALS, FINANCIAL COUNSELLOR, IMF: Well, I think that the biggest threat to global financial stability is that governments in various countries may not have enough political resolve to take the important measures which are needed to deal with the legacy of the crisis.

HUDSON: Vinals thinks that the global economy has gained ground despite slowing recently. He sees it accelerating in the second half of the year.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Let's check now at the stories in tonight's NBR news wheel. With jobs still scarce and gas prices still high, consumers are feeling down. A new survey on consumer sentiment from Reuters University of Michigan shows a drop in confidence. The consumer sentiment index fell to 71.8. Economists had expected a higher, more positive number. And more evidence today of just how grim the job market is. The Labor Department says last month that the unemployment rate fell in fewer than half of the nation's states. May's jobless rate was down in 24 states, up in 13 and unchanged in 13, showing job growth has stalled across much of the country.

And still ahead on the program tonight, tonight's "Market Monitor" takes on financial stocks. Bernie Schaeffer tells us if he thinks the year's worst performing stock sector is ready for a rebound. He's chairman of Schaeffer's Investment Research.

HUDSON: Exports have been a bright spot for the U.S. economy this year, helping boost growth and create American jobs. But new trade deals with Panama, Colombia and South Korea have been stalled in Congress for months on Capitol Hill. That standoff may end soon. Washington bureau chief Darren Gersh spoke with U.S. trade representative Ron Kirk. Kirk also is the former major of Dallas, Texas. Darren began by asking why it's been so hard to pass these trade agreements.

AMB. RON KIRK, U.S. TRADE REPRESENTATIVE: Well, because you're in Washington. And everything is, you know, everything is hard in this town. But the reason that we took the time to look at Korea and Panama and Colombia, not just from the standpoint of what does it take to pass them, but look at them in the broader context, that what 95 percent of the world's consumers somewhere other than the United States, part of our success in the future is going to be linked to our ability to take more of what we make, manufacture, innovate, create here in the U.S. and share it with the world. And so within that, you've got to have a trade policy that not only speaks to those that say hey, pass these agreements, get going, we need the market access. But you've also got to have a trade policy that reflects those that say we want to make sure our trade reflects our core values, particularly how you ought to treat workers, not just here but also around the world. And that passing the agreements with trade adjustment assistance gives us the best chance to have a balanced approach.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Right, but Republicans argue that trade adjustment assistance which helps workers who lose their jobs because of trade, they don't want it. They say that it's not an effective program. They want to pass these agreements without it. Why is that such a priority for the administration?

KIRK: Well, Democrats on the other hand say trade has become a primer for shipping our jobs overseas. And the trades, you know, the unfair trade deals are the reason we've seen manufacturing and they don't want the trade deals. Well, the reality and part of our challenge in this administration, what President Obama tasks me to do is say we've got to find common ground. There's no way we're going to disadvantage American exporters and manufacturers by saying we're going to put us on less favorable terms in these markets that other countries are getting. But at the same time, we can't dismiss the concerns of those that have said honestly that a lot of Americans, through no fault of their own, that happen to work for an industry that may have been displaced by trade, they typically are 46 years old, Anglo and the sole breadwinner of their family and they have good skills. And if we can get them the training, the coaching that they need, they can become reemployed. We not only save their job, we keep those families intact. And in many cases we keep those communities intact.

GERSH: But really what this comes down to is how are you going to do? How are you going to get this done because many of our biggest trade programs are on hold right now, have expired. How are you going to get this done and when?

KIRK: All along we have made a point. Our goal was not just to pass a trade agreement. We're trying to build a new paradigm and a new rationale to the American public that is increasingly skeptical about trade, about how we can do trade in a different way. And for us there has to be that holistic approach that you combine new market access through trade agreements with strong enforcement, which we've done at USTR and we reflect our core values as represented by our commitment to trade adjustment assistance. That's how you get it done. And we're closer than I think most people think we are.

GERSH: The president has set a goal of doubling exports, but everybody else in the world has set a goal of expanding exports. Everybody can't export their way out of their problems. How is it going to work?

KIRK: We can, it is work. And the one good thing is you know the president laid out that marker two years ago and remarkably we're well on pace to meeting that. One of the things helping to drive our economic recovery is the reality that exports and only 13 percent of our GDP are contributing almost as much to our economic recovery as consumer spending.

GERSH: Well, U.S. trade representative and Mavericks fan Ron Kirk, thank you very much for your time.

KIRK: Huge Mavericks fan. Thank you.

GHARIB: And a U-turn today for one of the nation's most powerful lobbies. AARP, which represents millions of older Americans said it is open to modest cuts in Social Security benefits for future recipients. The group has been a leading opponent of cutting benefits. But AARP now says it wants to limit any changes in benefits, while making sure the system remains solvent.

Well, Tom, it was a choppy week to be an understatement. And now investors have a weekend to think things over and start all over again on Monday.

HUDSON: Start all over again and of course always looking to Europe over the weekend, really, for the clues that we're going to see on Monday. But it was quite a day today here, Susie. Let's go ahead and roll with tonight's "Market Focus." We had a mixed finish for the major indices for the second day in a row. Investors still trying to balance the threat of European government debt against the consistency of lower energy prices that we've seen over the past several sessions. Let's start by updating where the S&P 500 is in relation back to its March low. There's that March low that we had back in the spring. This remains an area of key technical support and so far, it is holding as we can see with the fractional rise we've got with in the S&P index. It bounced off that level. The market has held above that March low, so far optimistic.

The slide in oil prices meantime, here's what the last 90 sessions in the front month crude oil contract in New York looked like. Crude here falling today another 2 percent. This is the lowest price that we've seen since February. Energy prices -- that may help the broad market lower prices, but it hurt energy stocks. Drilling company Nabors falling almost 4 percent. Oil producer Hess (NYSE: HES) dropping 1.5 percent. That's a new 2011 low for Hess (NYSE: HES). And equipment company National Oilwell Varco shed just over 1 percent. These were the leading energy stock losers today in that sector.

Technology stocks also weak and check out Google (NASDAQ: GOOG) here. Continues to see money coming out of its share price, sinking another 3 percent today. This is Google (NASDAQ: GOOG)'s lowest price that we've seen in many months since September of last year. An analyst at investment banking firm Raymond James reports that paid online search spending is slowing down for the industry. Clearly that's taken a chunk out of Google (NASDAQ: GOOG). Google (NASDAQ: GOOG)'s smartphone operating system Android is part of the challenge for Research in Motion (NASDAQ: RIMM)'s Blackberry. RIMM shares just got crushed today, very active trading. Look at this, 21.5 percent lower, losing more than a fifth of its value. This is just the past 30 sessions where you see the trend lower and then just falling off a shelf today. Volume exploding because of that sour outlook that we told you about last night. Let's pull out to the past five years, showing this recent drop really in context and here it is over the past several months with RIMM, now in fact below the March of '09 low. Remember this is the low for the broader market. We're seeing prices here in RIMM 27 3/4. We haven't seen that since the fall of 2006. Now we do have an analysis of Research in Motion (NASDAQ: RIMM)'s chart on our website. Go to NBR on pbs.org.

A couple of other big tech stocks that are in the Dow Industrial index. Cisco dropping another half percent, just pennies above its most recent 52-week low. The company has struggled with disappointing guidance trying to restructure. Cisco is the worst Dow stock this year. Since January, we've got it down 25 percent.

Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) meantime the best Dow stock today with a 1.2 percent rally. It's also though negative for the year as it continues to trend lower for tech. The worst stock sector this year, financials, not today though. Real estate service firm CB Richard Ellis jumping more than 4.5 percent. Tennessee-based bank First Horizon gaining almost 4 percent. And Zion bank out of Utah up about 3.5 percent, helping out the financials. According to the "Wall Street Journal," PNC Financial meantime is the winner in the bidding war for the U.S. retail operation of Royal Bank of Canada. No confirmation. Here's PNC shares trending lower here, along with the rest of the financial sector, slipping almost 3 percent. Heavy volume, this is the lowest price of PNC since December.

The "Journal" also reports securities regulators are considering civil charges against credit rating agencies. Moody's shares dropping 5 percent on this news. Parent company of Standard & Poor's, McGraw-Hill falling 3.6 percent.

We saw a trio of new stocks going public this week, get you updated here, a couple of high profile issues. Bankrate.com sold its stock at $15 today for the first time, rising a tad. Internet radio provider Pandora Media started at $16. It's below that IPO price tonight. And oil and nat gas services company Compressco Partners began at $20 and it slipped from there. That is tonight's "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Former Washington Mutual CEO Kerry Killinger and other top Wamu executives are in talks with the FDIC to settle a nearly $1 billion lawsuit filed against them. Killinger has until to the end of this month to respond to the FDIC's complaint against him. Regulators allege Wamu executives took extreme risks with the bank's mortgage portfolio, which led to the largest bank failure in U.S. history.

Meanwhile, another former bank executive is headed to prison for eight years. Catherine Kissick (ph) used to head a mortgage division at the now- defunct Colonial Bank. She learned her punishment today. Prosecutors say Kissick's role in a $3 billion fraud scheme led to Colonial's demise, as well as to Taylor Bean and Whitaker -- one of the nation's largest private mortgage companies. Taylor Bean's former chairman and owner Lee Farkas (ph) is due to be sentenced later this month.

HUDSON: Here's what we're watching for next week. Our scheduled Friday "Market Monitor" guest Alan Lancz. He's editor of the "Lancz Letter." The Federal Reserve will be back in the spotlight. It begins a two-day meeting on Tuesday next week. Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke will hold a news conference on Wednesday. Monday on the program, creating jobs during challenging economic times. We talk to state leaders about what the role of government should be.

GHARIB: Food prices will likely head higher over the next decade. That's what the United Nations and the Organization for Economic Corporation and Development are predicting. The reason - rising commodities prices and demand. The groups fear that higher food prices will hurt the world's poor who already spend as much as 80 percent of their income on food.

HUDSON: The fight against Medicare and Medicaid fraud goes high tech next month. That's when the Federal government begins using new software aimed at flagging would-be criminals before they get a check from Uncle Sam. Medicare has awarded a $77 million contract for the new system to defense giant Northrop Grumman (NYSE: NOC) and a group of companies. They'll use technology that's similar to that of banking and telecommunication companies to spot fraud.

Greece, jobs, housing. There is no shortage of worries for investors and that may be one reason to get more optimistic. So says tonight's "Market Monitor." Bernie Schaeffer back with us, chairman of Schaeffer's Investment Research, publisher of the "Option Advisor Market Letter." Always nice to see you Bernie. Welcome back.

BERNIE SCHAEFFER, CHMN., SCHAEFFER'S INVESTMENT RESEARCH: Thank you, Tom.

HUDSON: It was January when you were here last and you said that the market was in a disbelief rally. Investors just didn't believe that stock prices deserved to move higher. We're in essentially the same place in the market today than we were back in January. What about the market rally?

SCHAEFFER: Still in disbelief. Got another magazine cover from "Time" recently, June 20th dated, talking about what economic recovery question mark, still no major end close equity mutual funds. Something interesting right here and now is the market is at a point, all the major averages are flat for the year. Very often you find that when you reach a benchmark like that, just as we did in March, it is time for a rally. People look to come in at points like that.

HUDSON: One of the places that has fueled this move back to flat is the financial space. The financial stocks are always seen as market leading. It's clearly led the market lower over the past six weeks. It's the worst performing sector so far this year. Are you saying, if the market can move higher from here, that bank stocks will as well?

SCHAEFFER: I think the bank stocks are an interesting short. And an interesting put by, simply because you mentioned that people were looking at the bank stocks and people were quite bullish on the bank stocks. Analysts are still extremely bullish. There are big fund planners in there if the sector had not been able to get out of its own way.

HUDSON: So you are bearish on banks?

SCHAEFFER: I bearish. This is the slope of hope that sectors decline on until you get the capitulation stage. So I think there is still a good short trade shaping up in the banking sector even though I'm bullish on the overall market.

HUDSON: You are using options here to play the downside that you expect in banks looking at the XLF, ticker symbol for the I shares, financial select. Here is the options trade, buy January 2012 at the money puts, the option to sell, a bearish call. It profits if this exchange- traded fund falls. It has clearly fallen a lot already. And you are expecting it to what move into the single digits, perhaps?

SCHAEFFER: That would be a home run on this option trade but you know, even if you got a 25 percent decline, that would be a very nice gain. And it's a good hedge for a sector that you might be bullish on.

HUDSON: So noted. You do like consumers and at least consumer stocks, specifically retail stocks. Here is the S&P retail exchange-traded fund, the XRT. You are looking at again January 2012 calls, a bullish call, an option to buy this exchange-traded fund. If the XRT moves up at the rallies, this option rallies in price as well. What's fueling retail?

SCHAEFFER: What's fueling the retail stocks is kind of the opposite of what the banking and financial stocks are having trouble with. The actual price action has been strong. Despite the fact that Wall Street is very skeptical on these stocks and so what that means is, this is the wall of worry that bullish sectors and markets climb. It means that sideline money is being drawn in reluctantly but steadily into sectors like retailers whose price action and earnings is positively surprising and potentially out of sectors like financial where the results are negatively surprising and the expectations are high.

HUDSON: That is your set-up for the next six months. Six months ago when you were here you had a couple of options plays. Let's look how these have turned out. You were essentially bullish on the I shares Russell 2000 exchange- traded fund, August at the money calls. The option price though is down 43 percent as the exchange-traded fund essentially has gone nowhere. So time decay is what option traders call this. Do you still like this?

SCHAEFFER: Yes. And time decay versus leverage is the conundrum of making money in buying options.

HUDSON: Meantime this one was a big strikeout. You lost all your money with the June at the money calls for the iPath S&P 500, VIX exchange- traded note. Essentially you were looking for volatility as a hedge which has actually gone down in the last six months even though it has ticked up here lately in the past few weeks.

SCHAEFFER: Right. And I would rather hedge sector to sector as we are talking about today.

HUDSON: So noted. What about disclosures for these options?

SCHAEFFER: I don't have positions in the XLF or XRT exchange-traded fund.

HUDSON: We're going to catch up in six months. Nice to see you again.

SCHAEFFER: Great, pleasure.

HUDSON: Bernie Schaeffer, Schaeffer Investment Research.

GHARIB: And finally tonight, the author who got kids and parents reading together has something new, but it's not a book. Harry Potter author JK Rowling will soon unveil her latest venture and all we know so far is that it's called Pottermore and it won't be a book. The site has few details, but links to a countdown clock marking the days and hours until the launch Tom and media watchers are speculating that the big announcement will be about some sort of online "Harry Potter" experience, perfect thing for you to do with your two boys.

HUDSON: I tell you. We're not quite there yet for the Harry Potter books but we will be in just a short few years, Susie. That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Friday night, June 17. Thanks for joining us. Have a great weekend, you as well Susie.

GHARIB: Same to you Tom and a happy Father's Day to you and all the other fathers in our audience. I'm Susie Gharib. Hope to see all of you again next week.

END
