TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: The tech sector heats up after the bell. New products drive strong earnings at Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) and amazon.com, but the stocks drop on the news.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: While this doesn`t look like a farm, Verizon (NYSE: VZ) is plowing over $1 billion into server farm Terremark. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, January 27.

HUDSON: Good evening and thanks for joining us tonight, the tech sector squarely in focus after the close Susie. From earnings at Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) and amazon.com to Verizon`s big deal for computer server farm Terremark worldwide, we`ve really got the tech active in after hours trading tonight.

GHARIB: Tom, it sure was. Let`s start off with Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT), a double surprise from the software giant tonight -- better than expected quarterly earnings and the numbers were released earlier than expected. The report was supposed to come out after the closing bell, but was accidentally released on the Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) web site 15 minutes early. Here are the numbers. Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) earned $0.77 a share in its fiscal second quarter. That was $0.09 more than estimates. Revenues also came in better than expected -- about $20 billion. The company credited the sales boost to business customers upgrading their computers and the debut of its Kinect controller for the X-box 360.

HUDSON: Susie, amazon.com also turned in quarterly results after the close tonight. It as well beat estimates this time by $0.03 per share. The sale of electronic books for its Kindle reader outpaced sales of old school paperback books. But expenses last quarter increased, thanks to marketing for the Kindle over the holidays as well as investments in its distribution systems. The stocks of Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) and Amazon were both down after these reports. But shares of Terremark were awfully strong in after hours trading, surging as much as 35 percent. Here`s why. Verizon (NYSE: VZ) offering almost $1.5 billion for the computer server farm, $19 per share is the offer. The deal is part of Verizon`s push into cloud computing. We`re going to have more on all this coming in tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Also today, big earnings from big CAT. Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) It posted a quarterly profit that quadrupled from a year ago. The world`s largest maker of construction and mining equipment earned $1.47 a share in the fourth quarter of last year. That`s $0.20 more than estimates. Revenues also came in a billion dollars more than expected, up 62 percent to almost $13 billion. Looking ahead, the company expects annual revenues to top $50 billion this year, bringing Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) back to pre-recession levels. So when I talked with CEO Doug Oberhelman today, I asked him where is all that growth going to come from?

DOUG OBERHELMAN, CHAIRMAN & CEO, CATTERPILLAR: We`re seeing growth in sales and revenue just about across the globe. And most industries with the exception of our turbine business and large reciprocating engines which we think are coming but they`ll be coming, the growth will be coming later. So geographically and industry and product wise, it`s sort of a nice ramp all across the spectrum in 2011.

GHARIB: Mr. Oberhelman, how about in the U.S.? How strong is the recovery going to be for Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) equipment?

OBERHELMAN: Well, the U.S. certainly has been slow coming out of the recession. There is no doubt we`re one of the last economies to the party. It is coming, however. And I`ve just been with groups of dealers and customers the last couple of weeks. They are a lot more optimistic today than they were a year ago. Now these are not big number increases, of course from very depressed levels in the last couple of years, but the anecdotes, the order level, the activity is definitely improving. We put out our December retail activity which showed a big increase in the United States and North America. So it`s coming, but slowly and frustratingly slow, I would say.

GHARIB: As you heard, President Obama in the state of the union address the other night is calling for more spending on our infrastructure, building a high speed rail system. Do you see that really happening and how would that translate into business for Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT)?

OBERHELMAN: Well, you`ve got two great questions there. I will take the second one first. If we see more infrastructure spending and when that money actually hits the ground, it will help us. But remember, infrastructure spending that starts today is months if not a year or two before it hits the ground. Secondly, we are watching a very I would say conservative fiscal level of spending around the U.S. not only at the Federal level and the states. And that`s a concern to us because on the one hand, the U.S. has to get its house in order as do most states. On the other hand we need to stimulate the economy, get people back to work so it is a real balance to achieve.

GHARIB: Now you always talk about a lot of growth in the emerging markets. How important is China for your growth plan?

OBERHELMAN: 1.4 billion people modernizing is a good thing for this planet, people coming out of poverty, moving up into the middle class. That`s good for all of us. We in America need those export jobs. In fact, we exported about $13.5 billion from the U.S. in 2010. That`s up almost a third from 2009. Sixty eight percent of our sales or so in 2010 were outside. So those external markets are important for Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) and for our workers.

GHARIB: All right so, when China talks about slowing down its economy, what kind of impact would that have on Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT)?

OBERHELMAN: Well, they have talked about this and executed pretty well over the years ups and downs, growth and then slowdowns. They probably need to break their economy a little bit. I don`t see how they can grow at double digit GDP growth rates forever. Having said that, a slowdown to 6, 7 8 percent is probably healthy. It doesn`t impact us all that much, but it is something they`ve got to keep their eye on, they`ve got to work hard at.

GHARIB: Let`s talk a little bit about jobs, because Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) actually has been rehiring over the past year and now with all the pickup in business that you are talking about, how many more people do you plan to hire in 2011?

OBERHELMAN: With a forecast going over $50 billion in 2011 we`re going to need more help to increase our production and do more of the things we`ve got to do. We`re to the going to put a number out. We don`t really have a forecast, but I`m confident as sales grow and we need more production, we will have more people working here a year from now than we do today.

GHARIB: That some good news for a lot of out of work Americans.

OBERHELMAN: It is.

GHARIB: Let`s talk about Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) stock. It was the best performing Dow stock last year and it is almost quadrupled since March of 2009. So where does the stock go from here?

OBERHELMAN: We`re focusing on earnings. We`re focusing on quality of our business, growing market share, expanding geographically, spending capital, position us for the future. As long as earnings increase, our stock price will go along with it. But I will not make a prediction on that one.

GHARIB: Fair enough Mr. Oberhelman thank you so much for your time. Nice talking with you.

OBERHELMAN: You bet. Thank you.

HUDSON: Let`s take a look at the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel. We`ve got stocks rising slightly ahead of all the tech news after the close. The Dow gained four points, the NASDAQ up 15, the S&P 500 added nearly three. Big board trading volume dipped below a billion shares, while NASDAQ volume held firmly above two billion shares. New claims for jobless benefits rose by 51,000 in the past week to 454,000. Economists think bad winter weather is to blame. They see the trend reversing next week. Durable goods orders meantime tumbled in December, falling 2.5 percent. That was a surprise, because an increase in big ticket, long-lasting items was expected.

And Standard & Poor`s downgraded Japan`s debt rating. The ratings agency says the world`s third largest economy is struggling under a huge debt load. Japan`s debt is more than double its GDP. Tomorrow on the program, still ahead rather tonight, stay with us. With gold prices down sharply since the start of the year, is gold losing its luster?

GHARIB: Wondering what caused the financial crisis? Well, now we know, maybe. The panel investigating the meltdown has finally released its report. And after months of digging, there`s still disagreement. Six Democrats on the panel say the regulatory system broke down, starting at the Federal Reserve. Financial firms bet too much, households borrowed too much and some players totally ignored ethics. But Republicans on the panel say there were actually 10 causes. Among them, worldwide credit and housing bubbles, too many toxic mortgages and credit rating agencies that didn`t do their jobs. Commission Chairman Phil Angelides says the bottom line is that the financial crisis didn`t have to happen.

PHIL ANGELIDES, CHMN., FINANCIAL CRISIS INQUIRY COMMISSION: The captains of finance and the public stewards of our financial system ignored warnings and importantly failed to question, to understand and to manage the evolving risks in a financial system that is so essential to the well being of our country. Theirs was a big miss, not a stumble.

GHARIB: The commission has posted hundreds of documents online. In one, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke says only one of the country`s big financial firms was on solid footing during the crisis. But he doesn`t say which one.

So Tom, 12,000 on the Dow, 1300 on the S&P during trading hours but didn`t close there. Psychologists who study investor behavior say that there is some worries about round numbers whence it comes to these milestones so didn`t happen today. Maybe it`s tomorrow or next week.

HUDSON: Maybe, lots of after hours news though that we mentioned at the top of the program could put a bit of a bid into the market by tomorrow. We`ll have to wait and see. But clearly those big round numbers are going to remain in focus here Susie. Speaking of, let`s get to tonight`s "Market Focus." Overall ahead of all that tech news after the close, we saw another day of slim gains, but any gains at these levels mean the major indices do hit new post-recession highs. Some of that though may be interrupted tomorrow, if the after hours trading is any action (sic). We will mention Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) here as we roll it out. We talked about the earnings at the top of the program. Here`s the last year of MSFT trading. The 52-week high was back in the springtime. Shares falling during the regular session after the close down about 1 percent. This high here tonight, this is the highest level since May for MSFT.

Meantime, amazon.com, it came in to tonight`s report really with some optimism, a nice 5 percent rally. Just last week, this was a new all-time high for AMZN. Revenues though in the fourth quarter were a bit less than anticipated. Shares fell as much as 10 percent below these numbers down below $170 per share after the close, one to watch tomorrow.

Another one in technology was computer data storage firm Sandisk also had some optimistic buying interest ahead of its quarterly results. Shares have had a nice 70 percent rally here over the last 12 months. After the close, the stock down as much as 3 percent, but did have a bit of a rebound from that level so it clearly another one to watch in technology tomorrow.

Now the tech deal we mentioned earlier, Verizon (NYSE: VZ) buying tech data center firm Terremark. Ahead of that news, Verizon (NYSE: VZ) saw small gains, while Terremark was up 2.5 percent. Remember this was before the news hit the tape. After the deal announcement, Terremark jumped over its buyout price of $19 per share.

In addition to the technology news after the close, a quartet of semiconductor-related stocks really saw some buying interest off of their earnings today. Cirrus Logic (NASDAQ: CRUS) jumping 19 percent. Earnings there almost doubled. Teradyne (NYSE: TER) jumped 12 percent. It makes semiconductor testing equipment. Earnings at Teradyne (NYSE: TER) more than tripled in the past quarter. Integrated Silicon added 10 percent. LSI Logic (NYSE: LSI), another chip maker, lost money last quarter, but did see revenue growth and the share price reflected some optimism.

Over on the broad market, consumer stocks really held back the overall market during the regular session. Sara Lee (NYSE: SLE) here, we see it fell another 5 percent. This high was set earlier this week. It has clearly moved well off of that level. The company had been looking for a buyer to offer $19 per share, has found one, according to "the Wall Street Journal." It now likely will separate its coffee and meat businesses. Share price continuing to take a bit of a dive here.

Colgate Palmolive meantime sliding 3 percent. This is the last 180 sessions on the screen, clearly a bit of volatility over the past six months or so. This is a six week low tonight. Earnings were OK. Revenue though a bit disappointing. The company warns of building pressure from high commodity prices. This may be a trend because the same issue is in play at P&G. Procter and Gamble`s latest quarter $0.03 better than estimates, but down from a year ago. Higher commodity costs clearly in play at P&G. It was the leading loser of the Dow Jones Industrial Average today thanks to the 3 percent drop we saw. Through the week, share price had been rallying, in fact hitting a nice new 52-week high just a couple of sessions ago, ahead of this latest quarterly result.

The other sizable loser in the DowAT&T (NYSE: T), down 2 percent. We`re taking just a look at the last 30 sessions here at AT&T (NYSE: T) and what`s interesting is we`ve got the most recent low. This was the same day that Verizon (NYSE: VZ) announced it would start selling the iPhone, breaking AT&T`s exclusivity. Earnings at AT&T (NYSE: T) a penny over forecast, but new customer growth slowed and that cost the share price.

Steel stocks have seen some volatility this week as they report higher earnings. Again, commodity costs, higher raw material costs one market worry. Nucor (NYSE: NUE) the latest to report. It lost money in the fourth quarter, thanks to high commodity costs. It and U.S. Steel dropped more than 2 percent. The world`s biggest steel maker, Acelor Mittal, fell as well today. And that is tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Gold has been a less-than-glittering investment lately. Investors leaving the largest exchange-traded gold fund have pushed prices to a three-month low. So far this month, gold has posted its biggest monthly loss in over a year. So is this a temporary pullback or is the metal losing its luster? Erika Miller reports.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Whether it`s a necklace or bracelet, gold will always be attractive as jewelry. But will it also be attractive as an investment? After nearly a decade of big gains, investors have been rushing out of gold this month. Ditto for the world`s biggest gold-backed exchange-traded fund which saw record redemptions this week. Analyst Paul Christopher blames the rally in the stock market for luring investors away from safe havens like gold.

PAUL CHRISTOPHER, SR. INT`L STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO ADVISORS: You want to think about gold as an alternative currency, so that when there are better prospects in other financial assets other than gold, then gold would naturally tend to suffer.

MILLER: He thinks stocks will outperform gold long term, especially if the global economy continues to recover. But Barclays analyst Suki Cooper thinks the retreat in gold is only short-term profit taking.

SUKI COOPER, METALS ANALYST, BARCLAYS CAPITAL: We expect gold prices to average a fresh annual record high of $1,495 per ounce. We expect prices to continue to build on their gains until the third quarter of 2011.

MILLER: She believes the factors behind gold`s rally the past few years are still firmly in place.

COOPER: If we are looking at the longer-term drivers in gold, they still very much remain intact. There`s the longer-term concerns such as currency debasement or concerns that inflation could spiral. Those factors are still their driving investment demand.

MILLER: Many gold analysts are watching to see if gold falls below the key technical level of $1,275 an ounce. If it does, expect a heavy wave of selling, particularly by options traders. Longer term, analysts say gold`s direction depends on interest rates and inflation.

CHRISTOPHER: U.S. inflation right around the 1 percent to 2 percent area, while yields are rising, would be a sign that the economy is gaining more traction, while inflation is not. And that would really put a damper on prospects for gold going forward.

MILLER: If gold prices continue to fall, investment interest may wane. But the flip side is better deals on jewelry. And analysts say a pick up in consumer demand could help support prices. Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

GHARIB: Earlier in the program, Caterpillar`s CEO talked about the importance of the Chinese market. But it`s not just construction companies that are experiencing a boon there. The western part of the country is seeing a surge in new business and jobs, thanks to government incentives. Nick Mackie takes a look.

NICK MACKIE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Cranes dot the skyline, building homes, high-rise office blocks and high tech factories. It`s a far cry from five years ago, when all this was mainly farmland. Over the past 18 months, $3 billion of inward investment has flowed into Xiyong micro- electronics park, with key players including Hewlett-Packard (NYSE: HPQ), Foxconn, Quanta, Inventec and Acer deciding to locate here. The park`s deputy director, Zhu Jiang, says Chongqing is now on track to be a global manufacturing base for notebooks and tablets.

TRANSLATION OF: ZHU JIANG, XIYONG MICRO-ELECTRONICS INDUSTRIAL PARK: By 2015, notebook production will reach 80 million units. Our exports will reach $80 million U.S. and 400,000 people will be employed in notebook manufacturing or related fields.

MACKIE: Companies are buying into Chongqing because they seek lower operational costs and to get closer to inland China`s huge maturing consumer base. The city recognized this early on and was quick to craft and finance its strategy to build a new industry from scratch. Labor and energy costs are 30 percent cheaper here than in China`s coastal region. But the downside for now, is that 90 percent of component makers are still over there, a thousand miles away. There are costly supply chain problems for parts coming in or goods bound for export . So the government offers incentives to compensate its early movers.

JIANG: Initially, the government provides subsidies to offset high logistics costs, to help the enterprises get over their early-stage difficulties. Once more and more companies locate here, there`ll be economies of scale and logistics costs should improve. Then, that`s when the government will step back.

MACKIE: As part of its strategy, the government first stepped forward in Xiyong five years ago by establishing a new university city, so that colleges and vocational schools could relocate from the main urban area. Chongqing`s college of electronic engineering, with 20,000 students, now supplies technicians and engineers for the tech-based industry. Its chief of enterprise cooperation, Mao Weiping, says companies work closely with the college and even provide machinery to ensure the right skill sets are developed.

TRANSLATION OF: MAO WEIPING, CHONGQING COLLEGE/ELECTRONIC ENGINEERING: Nearly half of our graduates go on to work for the micro-electronics park and its related industry. Also each year, we send about 2,000 to 3,000 students to the park`s companies for work-related experience.

MACKIE: While Chongqing`s labor pool is strong on low-skilled and mid- level workers, it`s weak, however, on retaining top flight engineers, who usually head for the established R&D centers in Beijing and Shanghai. With the cost of living soaring in China`s premier cities, Chongqing believes more engineers will seek opportunities here, notably when the big tech players shift up a gear. Xiyong illustrates that, even in a once backwater, if the local government`s vision is global, the support strong and the execution fast, leading corporations are quick off the blocks to back Chinese-style state-controlled capitalism in order to grow in a competitive marketplace. Nick Mackie, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Chongqing.

HUDSON: Here`s what we`re watching for tomorrow: our "Market Monitor" scheduled to be Erik Ristuben, chief investment officer of client investment strategies at Russell Investments. Did the U.S. economy grow during the last three months of the year and how much? We`ll get a first look at fourth quarter GDP tomorrow. And Ford Motor expected to post its best yearly profit in more than a decade. We`ll ask CEO Alan Mulally what`s driving business.

GHARIB: Linked In could be the first of the big social networking companies to go public. The site aimed at connecting business professionals with other professionals filed with regulators today for an initial public offering. But Linked In did not say how much money it`s hoping to raise or when it will do the offering. Other social network firms are expected to follow in Linked In. Groupon and Facebook are set to go public over the next 18 months.

HUDSON: Shares of Bank United begin trading tomorrow at the New York Stock Exchange. Late today, they priced at $27 per share. That`s $2 more than the expected range. The bank raised $783 million. We`ll talk with CEO John Kanas, tomorrow. He himself invested $23 million in the bank when it was bought by private equity firms, including WL Ross, Blackstone and Carlyle Group back in 2009.

GHARIB: With high unemployment and a shaky outlook for housing, you`d think consumers would stay away from the stores and stop shopping altogether. But last month, shoppers were out in full force, ringing up the best holiday season in four years. Tonight`s commentator says there`s a good reason for it. He`s Bernard Baumohl, chief global economist at the Economic Outlook Group.

BERNARD BAUMOHL, CHIEF GLOBAL ECON., ECONOMIC OUTLOOK GROUP: The year 2010 left us with a tantalizing puzzle. We know the unemployment numbers were awful last year, the worst in 30 years. And yet, even with that dismal record, Americans were enthusiastic shoppers. Retail sales shot up by the most in more than a decade. You would think high joblessness would cool household spending, but it didn`t and one major reason may be that the U.S. has a thriving underground economy. By underground economy, I`m not talking about illicit activity, like selling stolen goods or drugs. It`s mostly legal work, where millions of unemployed find income by doing handyman work or selling stuff at flea markets or repairing computers.

Given the job-destroying recession we just had, it is believed a record number of cash-strapped Americans were driven into the shadowy underground. By some estimates, the size of the underground economy has swollen from $350 billion a decade ago to $1.5 trillion now or more than 10 percent of the GDP. While business in the underground economy are typically done off the books and deprive the government of needed revenues, they can serve an important source of stimulus during periods of economic weakness and may in part explain why we had this odd combination of high unemployment and robust consumer spending. I`m Bernard Baumohl.

GHARIB: And that`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, January 27. Good night, everyone and good night to you, Tom.

HUDSON: Have a great night, Susie. I`m Tom Hudson. Thanks for joining us and we`ll see you right back here tomorrow night.

END

urn:contentItem:5224-D521-JBKP-N089-00000-00Nightly Business Report2011-01-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:43ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT6:30 PM ESTBUSINESS012701cb.118Nightly Business ReportTom Hudson, Susie Gharib

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: The tech sector heats up after the bell. New products drive strong earnings at Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) and amazon.com, but the stocks drop on the news.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: While this doesn`t look like a farm, Verizon (NYSE: VZ) is plowing over $1 billion into server farm Terremark. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, January 27.

HUDSON: Good evening and thanks for joining us tonight, the tech sector squarely in focus after the close Susie. From earnings at Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) and amazon.com to Verizon`s big deal for computer server farm Terremark worldwide, we`ve really got the tech active in after hours trading tonight.

GHARIB: Tom, it sure was. Let`s start off with Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT), a double surprise from the software giant tonight -- better than expected quarterly earnings and the numbers were released earlier than expected. The report was supposed to come out after the closing bell, but was accidentally released on the Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) web site 15 minutes early. Here are the numbers. Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) earned $0.77 a share in its fiscal second quarter. That was $0.09 more than estimates. Revenues also came in better than expected -- about $20 billion. The company credited the sales boost to business customers upgrading their computers and the debut of its Kinect controller for the X-box 360.

HUDSON: Susie, amazon.com also turned in quarterly results after the close tonight. It as well beat estimates this time by $0.03 per share. The sale of electronic books for its Kindle reader outpaced sales of old school paperback books. But expenses last quarter increased, thanks to marketing for the Kindle over the holidays as well as investments in its distribution systems. The stocks of Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) and Amazon were both down after these reports. But shares of Terremark were awfully strong in after hours trading, surging as much as 35 percent. Here`s why. Verizon (NYSE: VZ) offering almost $1.5 billion for the computer server farm, $19 per share is the offer. The deal is part of Verizon`s push into cloud computing. We`re going to have more on all this coming in tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Also today, big earnings from big CAT. Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) It posted a quarterly profit that quadrupled from a year ago. The world`s largest maker of construction and mining equipment earned $1.47 a share in the fourth quarter of last year. That`s $0.20 more than estimates. Revenues also came in a billion dollars more than expected, up 62 percent to almost $13 billion. Looking ahead, the company expects annual revenues to top $50 billion this year, bringing Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) back to pre-recession levels. So when I talked with CEO Doug Oberhelman today, I asked him where is all that growth going to come from?

DOUG OBERHELMAN, CHAIRMAN & CEO, CATTERPILLAR: We`re seeing growth in sales and revenue just about across the globe. And most industries with the exception of our turbine business and large reciprocating engines which we think are coming but they`ll be coming, the growth will be coming later. So geographically and industry and product wise, it`s sort of a nice ramp all across the spectrum in 2011.

GHARIB: Mr. Oberhelman, how about in the U.S.? How strong is the recovery going to be for Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) equipment?

OBERHELMAN: Well, the U.S. certainly has been slow coming out of the recession. There is no doubt we`re one of the last economies to the party. It is coming, however. And I`ve just been with groups of dealers and customers the last couple of weeks. They are a lot more optimistic today than they were a year ago. Now these are not big number increases, of course from very depressed levels in the last couple of years, but the anecdotes, the order level, the activity is definitely improving. We put out our December retail activity which showed a big increase in the United States and North America. So it`s coming, but slowly and frustratingly slow, I would say.

GHARIB: As you heard, President Obama in the state of the union address the other night is calling for more spending on our infrastructure, building a high speed rail system. Do you see that really happening and how would that translate into business for Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT)?

OBERHELMAN: Well, you`ve got two great questions there. I will take the second one first. If we see more infrastructure spending and when that money actually hits the ground, it will help us. But remember, infrastructure spending that starts today is months if not a year or two before it hits the ground. Secondly, we are watching a very I would say conservative fiscal level of spending around the U.S. not only at the Federal level and the states. And that`s a concern to us because on the one hand, the U.S. has to get its house in order as do most states. On the other hand we need to stimulate the economy, get people back to work so it is a real balance to achieve.

GHARIB: Now you always talk about a lot of growth in the emerging markets. How important is China for your growth plan?

OBERHELMAN: 1.4 billion people modernizing is a good thing for this planet, people coming out of poverty, moving up into the middle class. That`s good for all of us. We in America need those export jobs. In fact, we exported about $13.5 billion from the U.S. in 2010. That`s up almost a third from 2009. Sixty eight percent of our sales or so in 2010 were outside. So those external markets are important for Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) and for our workers.

GHARIB: All right so, when China talks about slowing down its economy, what kind of impact would that have on Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT)?

OBERHELMAN: Well, they have talked about this and executed pretty well over the years ups and downs, growth and then slowdowns. They probably need to break their economy a little bit. I don`t see how they can grow at double digit GDP growth rates forever. Having said that, a slowdown to 6, 7 8 percent is probably healthy. It doesn`t impact us all that much, but it is something they`ve got to keep their eye on, they`ve got to work hard at.

GHARIB: Let`s talk a little bit about jobs, because Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) actually has been rehiring over the past year and now with all the pickup in business that you are talking about, how many more people do you plan to hire in 2011?

OBERHELMAN: With a forecast going over $50 billion in 2011 we`re going to need more help to increase our production and do more of the things we`ve got to do. We`re to the going to put a number out. We don`t really have a forecast, but I`m confident as sales grow and we need more production, we will have more people working here a year from now than we do today.

GHARIB: That some good news for a lot of out of work Americans.

OBERHELMAN: It is.

GHARIB: Let`s talk about Caterpillar (NYSE: CAT) stock. It was the best performing Dow stock last year and it is almost quadrupled since March of 2009. So where does the stock go from here?

OBERHELMAN: We`re focusing on earnings. We`re focusing on quality of our business, growing market share, expanding geographically, spending capital, position us for the future. As long as earnings increase, our stock price will go along with it. But I will not make a prediction on that one.

GHARIB: Fair enough Mr. Oberhelman thank you so much for your time. Nice talking with you.

OBERHELMAN: You bet. Thank you.

HUDSON: Let`s take a look at the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel. We`ve got stocks rising slightly ahead of all the tech news after the close. The Dow gained four points, the NASDAQ up 15, the S&P 500 added nearly three. Big board trading volume dipped below a billion shares, while NASDAQ volume held firmly above two billion shares. New claims for jobless benefits rose by 51,000 in the past week to 454,000. Economists think bad winter weather is to blame. They see the trend reversing next week. Durable goods orders meantime tumbled in December, falling 2.5 percent. That was a surprise, because an increase in big ticket, long-lasting items was expected.

And Standard & Poor`s downgraded Japan`s debt rating. The ratings agency says the world`s third largest economy is struggling under a huge debt load. Japan`s debt is more than double its GDP. Tomorrow on the program, still ahead rather tonight, stay with us. With gold prices down sharply since the start of the year, is gold losing its luster?

GHARIB: Wondering what caused the financial crisis? Well, now we know, maybe. The panel investigating the meltdown has finally released its report. And after months of digging, there`s still disagreement. Six Democrats on the panel say the regulatory system broke down, starting at the Federal Reserve. Financial firms bet too much, households borrowed too much and some players totally ignored ethics. But Republicans on the panel say there were actually 10 causes. Among them, worldwide credit and housing bubbles, too many toxic mortgages and credit rating agencies that didn`t do their jobs. Commission Chairman Phil Angelides says the bottom line is that the financial crisis didn`t have to happen.

PHIL ANGELIDES, CHMN., FINANCIAL CRISIS INQUIRY COMMISSION: The captains of finance and the public stewards of our financial system ignored warnings and importantly failed to question, to understand and to manage the evolving risks in a financial system that is so essential to the well being of our country. Theirs was a big miss, not a stumble.

GHARIB: The commission has posted hundreds of documents online. In one, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke says only one of the country`s big financial firms was on solid footing during the crisis. But he doesn`t say which one.

So Tom, 12,000 on the Dow, 1300 on the S&P during trading hours but didn`t close there. Psychologists who study investor behavior say that there is some worries about round numbers whence it comes to these milestones so didn`t happen today. Maybe it`s tomorrow or next week.

HUDSON: Maybe, lots of after hours news though that we mentioned at the top of the program could put a bit of a bid into the market by tomorrow. We`ll have to wait and see. But clearly those big round numbers are going to remain in focus here Susie. Speaking of, let`s get to tonight`s "Market Focus." Overall ahead of all that tech news after the close, we saw another day of slim gains, but any gains at these levels mean the major indices do hit new post-recession highs. Some of that though may be interrupted tomorrow, if the after hours trading is any action (sic). We will mention Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) here as we roll it out. We talked about the earnings at the top of the program. Here`s the last year of MSFT trading. The 52-week high was back in the springtime. Shares falling during the regular session after the close down about 1 percent. This high here tonight, this is the highest level since May for MSFT.

Meantime, amazon.com, it came in to tonight`s report really with some optimism, a nice 5 percent rally. Just last week, this was a new all-time high for AMZN. Revenues though in the fourth quarter were a bit less than anticipated. Shares fell as much as 10 percent below these numbers down below $170 per share after the close, one to watch tomorrow.

Another one in technology was computer data storage firm Sandisk also had some optimistic buying interest ahead of its quarterly results. Shares have had a nice 70 percent rally here over the last 12 months. After the close, the stock down as much as 3 percent, but did have a bit of a rebound from that level so it clearly another one to watch in technology tomorrow.

Now the tech deal we mentioned earlier, Verizon (NYSE: VZ) buying tech data center firm Terremark. Ahead of that news, Verizon (NYSE: VZ) saw small gains, while Terremark was up 2.5 percent. Remember this was before the news hit the tape. After the deal announcement, Terremark jumped over its buyout price of $19 per share.

In addition to the technology news after the close, a quartet of semiconductor-related stocks really saw some buying interest off of their earnings today. Cirrus Logic (NASDAQ: CRUS) jumping 19 percent. Earnings there almost doubled. Teradyne (NYSE: TER) jumped 12 percent. It makes semiconductor testing equipment. Earnings at Teradyne (NYSE: TER) more than tripled in the past quarter. Integrated Silicon added 10 percent. LSI Logic (NYSE: LSI), another chip maker, lost money last quarter, but did see revenue growth and the share price reflected some optimism.

Over on the broad market, consumer stocks really held back the overall market during the regular session. Sara Lee (NYSE: SLE) here, we see it fell another 5 percent. This high was set earlier this week. It has clearly moved well off of that level. The company had been looking for a buyer to offer $19 per share, has found one, according to "the Wall Street Journal." It now likely will separate its coffee and meat businesses. Share price continuing to take a bit of a dive here.

Colgate Palmolive meantime sliding 3 percent. This is the last 180 sessions on the screen, clearly a bit of volatility over the past six months or so. This is a six week low tonight. Earnings were OK. Revenue though a bit disappointing. The company warns of building pressure from high commodity prices. This may be a trend because the same issue is in play at P&G. Procter and Gamble`s latest quarter $0.03 better than estimates, but down from a year ago. Higher commodity costs clearly in play at P&G. It was the leading loser of the Dow Jones Industrial Average today thanks to the 3 percent drop we saw. Through the week, share price had been rallying, in fact hitting a nice new 52-week high just a couple of sessions ago, ahead of this latest quarterly result.

The other sizable loser in the Dow AT&T (NYSE: T), down 2 percent. We`re taking just a look at the last 30 sessions here at AT&T (NYSE: T) and what`s interesting is we`ve got the most recent low. This was the same day that Verizon (NYSE: VZ) announced it would start selling the iPhone, breaking AT&T`s exclusivity. Earnings at AT&T (NYSE: T) a penny over forecast, but new customer growth slowed and that cost the share price.

Steel stocks have seen some volatility this week as they report higher earnings. Again, commodity costs, higher raw material costs one market worry. Nucor (NYSE: NUE) the latest to report. It lost money in the fourth quarter, thanks to high commodity costs. It and U.S. Steel dropped more than 2 percent. The world`s biggest steel maker, Acelor Mittal, fell as well today. And that is tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Gold has been a less-than-glittering investment lately. Investors leaving the largest exchange-traded gold fund have pushed prices to a three-month low. So far this month, gold has posted its biggest monthly loss in over a year. So is this a temporary pullback or is the metal losing its luster? Erika Miller reports.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Whether it`s a necklace or bracelet, gold will always be attractive as jewelry. But will it also be attractive as an investment? After nearly a decade of big gains, investors have been rushing out of gold this month. Ditto for the world`s biggest gold-backed exchange-traded fund which saw record redemptions this week. Analyst Paul Christopher blames the rally in the stock market for luring investors away from safe havens like gold.

PAUL CHRISTOPHER, SR. INT`L STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO ADVISORS: You want to think about gold as an alternative currency, so that when there are better prospects in other financial assets other than gold, then gold would naturally tend to suffer.

MILLER: He thinks stocks will outperform gold long term, especially if the global economy continues to recover. But Barclays analyst Suki Cooper thinks the retreat in gold is only short-term profit taking.

SUKI COOPER, METALS ANALYST, BARCLAYS CAPITAL: We expect gold prices to average a fresh annual record high of $1,495 per ounce. We expect prices to continue to build on their gains until the third quarter of 2011.

MILLER: She believes the factors behind gold`s rally the past few years are still firmly in place.

COOPER: If we are looking at the longer-term drivers in gold, they still very much remain intact. There`s the longer-term concerns such as currency debasement or concerns that inflation could spiral. Those factors are still their driving investment demand.

MILLER: Many gold analysts are watching to see if gold falls below the key technical level of $1,275 an ounce. If it does, expect a heavy wave of selling, particularly by options traders. Longer term, analysts say gold`s direction depends on interest rates and inflation.

CHRISTOPHER: U.S. inflation right around the 1 percent to 2 percent area, while yields are rising, would be a sign that the economy is gaining more traction, while inflation is not. And that would really put a damper on prospects for gold going forward.

MILLER: If gold prices continue to fall, investment interest may wane. But the flip side is better deals on jewelry. And analysts say a pick up in consumer demand could help support prices. Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

GHARIB: Earlier in the program, Caterpillar`s CEO talked about the importance of the Chinese market. But it`s not just construction companies that are experiencing a boon there. The western part of the country is seeing a surge in new business and jobs, thanks to government incentives. Nick Mackie takes a look.

NICK MACKIE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Cranes dot the skyline, building homes, high-rise office blocks and high tech factories. It`s a far cry from five years ago, when all this was mainly farmland. Over the past 18 months, $3 billion of inward investment has flowed into Xiyong micro- electronics park, with key players including Hewlett-Packard (NYSE: HPQ), Foxconn, Quanta, Inventec and Acer deciding to locate here. The park`s deputy director, Zhu Jiang, says Chongqing is now on track to be a global manufacturing base for notebooks and tablets.

TRANSLATION OF: ZHU JIANG, XIYONG MICRO-ELECTRONICS INDUSTRIAL PARK: By 2015, notebook production will reach 80 million units. Our exports will reach $80 million U.S. and 400,000 people will be employed in notebook manufacturing or related fields.

MACKIE: Companies are buying into Chongqing because they seek lower operational costs and to get closer to inland China`s huge maturing consumer base. The city recognized this early on and was quick to craft and finance its strategy to build a new industry from scratch. Labor and energy costs are 30 percent cheaper here than in China`s coastal region. But the downside for now, is that 90 percent of component makers are still over there, a thousand miles away. There are costly supply chain problems for parts coming in or goods bound for export . So the government offers incentives to compensate its early movers.

JIANG: Initially, the government provides subsidies to offset high logistics costs, to help the enterprises get over their early-stage difficulties. Once more and more companies locate here, there`ll be economies of scale and logistics costs should improve. Then, that`s when the government will step back.

MACKIE: As part of its strategy, the government first stepped forward in Xiyong five years ago by establishing a new university city, so that colleges and vocational schools could relocate from the main urban area. Chongqing`s college of electronic engineering, with 20,000 students, now supplies technicians and engineers for the tech-based industry. Its chief of enterprise cooperation, Mao Weiping, says companies work closely with the college and even provide machinery to ensure the right skill sets are developed.

TRANSLATION OF: MAO WEIPING, CHONGQING COLLEGE/ELECTRONIC ENGINEERING: Nearly half of our graduates go on to work for the micro-electronics park and its related industry. Also each year, we send about 2,000 to 3,000 students to the park`s companies for work-related experience.

MACKIE: While Chongqing`s labor pool is strong on low-skilled and mid- level workers, it`s weak, however, on retaining top flight engineers, who usually head for the established R&D centers in Beijing and Shanghai. With the cost of living soaring in China`s premier cities, Chongqing believes more engineers will seek opportunities here, notably when the big tech players shift up a gear. Xiyong illustrates that, even in a once backwater, if the local government`s vision is global, the support strong and the execution fast, leading corporations are quick off the blocks to back Chinese-style state-controlled capitalism in order to grow in a competitive marketplace. Nick Mackie, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Chongqing.

HUDSON: Here`s what we`re watching for tomorrow: our "Market Monitor" scheduled to be Erik Ristuben, chief investment officer of client investment strategies at Russell Investments. Did the U.S. economy grow during the last three months of the year and how much? We`ll get a first look at fourth quarter GDP tomorrow. And Ford Motor expected to post its best yearly profit in more than a decade. We`ll ask CEO Alan Mulally what`s driving business.

GHARIB: Linked In could be the first of the big social networking companies to go public. The site aimed at connecting business professionals with other professionals filed with regulators today for an initial public offering. But Linked In did not say how much money it`s hoping to raise or when it will do the offering. Other social network firms are expected to follow in Linked In. Groupon and Facebook are set to go public over the next 18 months.

HUDSON: Shares of Bank United begin trading tomorrow at the New York Stock Exchange. Late today, they priced at $27 per share. That`s $2 more than the expected range. The bank raised $783 million. We`ll talk with CEO John Kanas, tomorrow. He himself invested $23 million in the bank when it was bought by private equity firms, including WL Ross, Blackstone and Carlyle Group back in 2009.

GHARIB: With high unemployment and a shaky outlook for housing, you`d think consumers would stay away from the stores and stop shopping altogether. But last month, shoppers were out in full force, ringing up the best holiday season in four years. Tonight`s commentator says there`s a good reason for it. He`s Bernard Baumohl, chief global economist at the Economic Outlook Group.

BERNARD BAUMOHL, CHIEF GLOBAL ECON., ECONOMIC OUTLOOK GROUP: The year 2010 left us with a tantalizing puzzle. We know the unemployment numbers were awful last year, the worst in 30 years. And yet, even with that dismal record, Americans were enthusiastic shoppers. Retail sales shot up by the most in more than a decade. You would think high joblessness would cool household spending, but it didn`t and one major reason may be that the U.S. has a thriving underground economy. By underground economy, I`m not talking about illicit activity, like selling stolen goods or drugs. It`s mostly legal work, where millions of unemployed find income by doing handyman work or selling stuff at flea markets or repairing computers.

Given the job-destroying recession we just had, it is believed a record number of cash-strapped Americans were driven into the shadowy underground. By some estimates, the size of the underground economy has swollen from $350 billion a decade ago to $1.5 trillion now or more than 10 percent of the GDP. While business in the underground economy are typically done off the books and deprive the government of needed revenues, they can serve an important source of stimulus during periods of economic weakness and may in part explain why we had this odd combination of high unemployment and robust consumer spending. I`m Bernard Baumohl.

GHARIB: And that`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, January 27. Good night, everyone and good night to you, Tom.

HUDSON: Have a great night, Susie. I`m Tom Hudson. Thanks for joining us and we`ll see you right back here tomorrow night.

urn:contentItem:534M-2SS1-JC11-90JK-00000-00Nightly Business Report2011-06-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:43ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT6:30 PM ESTBUSINESS061701cb.118Nightly Business ReportTom Hudson, Susie Gharib

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Better news out of Greece gives U.S. stocks a better day, but worries persist.

JONATHAN CORPINA: We`ve had a very successful run-up in our market over the last year and a half, but any headline that comes out of Greece that shows the country has the possibility of defaulting would truly have a global economic effect.

HUDSON: From Greece to Wall Street, we wrap up what`s been a rocky week for investors. It`s NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Friday, June 17.

Good evening and thanks for joining us tonight. Some cautious signs of relief by investors around the world today. There`s a rescue plan in the works for Greece. Jittery financial markets stabilized somewhat after Germany agreed to a compromise deal to resolve the economic problems in Greece. U.S. stocks took that news and finished mixed today. The Dow Industrials was able to gain 42 points; the S&P slipped more than seven, rather the NASDAQ slipped more than seven. The S&P 500 gained almost four.

Now here`s how things looked for what was a rough week for investors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average added almost 1.5 percent. That snapped a six-week losing streak. The NASDAQ though didn`t fare as well, falling 1 percent for the week. The S&P turned positive this week, ending a six-week slide, adding just a fraction. Despite today`s market rebound of sorts in America, investors are still worried about Greece. As Suzanne Pratt reports, Americans will be following the Greek drama closely for weeks to come.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Recently Greece has gone from being viewed as a fabulous tourist spot to a thorn in the side of U.S. stock investors. The question now is whether Greece and its financial woes will dictate the direction of the American stock market for the immediate future. NYSE trader Jonathan Corpina says it absolutely will because investors hate uncertainty and Greece`s financial outlook is far from certain.

JONATHAN CORPINA: Until we have some stability, any information about a plan or some sort of recovery that`s put in place coming out of Europe and Greece at that point then investors will feel much more confident to get back in the market. Looking into today, markets are positive this morning and leading into the afternoon due to the fact that the headlines are coming our of Greece.

PRATT: Market strategist Rick Bensignor agrees positive news out of Greece is just as important for U.S. investors as negative.

RICK BENSIGNOR, MARKET STRATEGIST: If by chance something good out over the weekend, a good headline or something like that, it wouldn`t surprise me if the S&P was up 20, 25 points on Monday, the Dow up a couple hundred points. Good news could easily turn the psychology very quickly.

PRATT: Still others say the issue right now for the U.S. stock market is that it`s in a bit of an information void. Reporting season for corporate profits is still nearly a month away and lately there`s been little major U.S. economic data for investors to chew on. As a result, every twist and turn across the pond with Greece and its weaker neighbors gets extra special attention on U.S. trading floors. And experts say investors should expect Greece and its debt troubles to remain in the headlines for some time.

BENSIGNOR: You can`t fix it for good over the weekend. It`s too big a problem with too far reaching circumstances. And, it`s not just Greece. Greece is just the one in the headlines the most these days. But, there`s a likelihood that this stuff spreads to Ireland, Spain and Portugal.

PRATT: One thing many market pros agree on is if Greece defaults on its government debt, it will mean big trouble for U.S. stocks. In fact, some estimate major market averages could quickly lose as much as 15 percent. Suzanne Pratt, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: While Greece`s debt woes are grabbing headlines tonight, Italy`s problems may be heating up. Late today, Moody`s investor service put Italy on review for possible downgrade. Moody`s is worried the country won`t be able to cut spending enough to reduce its debt.

Back here in the U.S. meantime, watch for slower economic growth. That`s what the International Monetary Fund predicts. The global lending agency today said it thinks the U.S. economy will grow 2.5 percent this year, 2.7 percent next year. Both are down from a previous estimate issued just two months ago. The IMF`s Jose Vinals says the U.S. and Eurozone nations are playing with fire, unless they take steps to cut their budget deficits immediately.

JOSE VINALS, FINANCIAL COUNSELLOR, IMF: Well, I think that the biggest threat to global financial stability is that governments in various countries may not have enough political resolve to take the important measures which are needed to deal with the legacy of the crisis.

HUDSON: Vinals thinks that the global economy has gained ground despite slowing recently. He sees it accelerating in the second half of the year.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Let`s check now at the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel. With jobs still scarce and gas prices still high, consumers are feeling down. A new survey on consumer sentiment from Reuters University of Michigan shows a drop in confidence. The consumer sentiment index fell to 71.8. Economists had expected a higher, more positive number. And more evidence today of just how grim the job market is. The Labor Department says last month that the unemployment rate fell in fewer than half of the nation`s states. May`s jobless rate was down in 24 states, up in 13 and unchanged in 13, showing job growth has stalled across much of the country.

And still ahead on the program tonight, tonight`s "Market Monitor" takes on financial stocks. Bernie Schaeffer tells us if he thinks the year`s worst performing stock sector is ready for a rebound. He`s chairman of Schaeffer`s Investment Research.

HUDSON: Exports have been a bright spot for the U.S. economy this year, helping boost growth and create American jobs. But new trade deals with Panama, Colombia and South Korea have been stalled in Congress for months on Capitol Hill. That standoff may end soon. Washington bureau chief Darren Gersh spoke with U.S. trade representative Ron Kirk. Kirk also is the former major of Dallas, Texas. Darren began by asking why it`s been so hard to pass these trade agreements.

AMB. RON KIRK, U.S. TRADE REPRESENTATIVE: Well, because you`re in Washington. And everything is, you know, everything is hard in this town. But the reason that we took the time to look at Korea and Panama and Colombia, not just from the standpoint of what does it take to pass them, but look at them in the broader context, that what 95 percent of the world`s consumers somewhere other than the United States, part of our success in the future is going to be linked to our ability to take more of what we make, manufacture, innovate, create here in the U.S. and share it with the world. And so within that, you`ve got to have a trade policy that not only speaks to those that say hey, pass these agreements, get going, we need the market access. But you`ve also got to have a trade policy that reflects those that say we want to make sure our trade reflects our core values, particularly how you ought to treat workers, not just here but also around the world. And that passing the agreements with trade adjustment assistance gives us the best chance to have a balanced approach.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Right, but Republicans argue that trade adjustment assistance which helps workers who lose their jobs because of trade, they don`t want it. They say that it`s not an effective program. They want to pass these agreements without it. Why is that such a priority for the administration?

KIRK: Well, Democrats on the other hand say trade has become a primer for shipping our jobs overseas. And the trades, you know, the unfair trade deals are the reason we`ve seen manufacturing and they don`t want the trade deals. Well, the reality and part of our challenge in this administration, what President Obama tasks me to do is say we`ve got to find common ground. There`s no way we`re going to disadvantage American exporters and manufacturers by saying we`re going to put us on less favorable terms in these markets that other countries are getting. But at the same time, we can`t dismiss the concerns of those that have said honestly that a lot of Americans, through no fault of their own, that happen to work for an industry that may have been displaced by trade, they typically are 46 years old, Anglo and the sole breadwinner of their family and they have good skills. And if we can get them the training, the coaching that they need, they can become reemployed. We not only save their job, we keep those families intact. And in many cases we keep those communities intact.

GERSH: But really what this comes down to is how are you going to do? How are you going to get this done because many of our biggest trade programs are on hold right now, have expired. How are you going to get this done and when?

KIRK: All along we have made a point. Our goal was not just to pass a trade agreement. We`re trying to build a new paradigm and a new rationale to the American public that is increasingly skeptical about trade, about how we can do trade in a different way. And for us there has to be that holistic approach that you combine new market access through trade agreements with strong enforcement, which we`ve done at USTR and we reflect our core values as represented by our commitment to trade adjustment assistance. That`s how you get it done. And we`re closer than I think most people think we are.

GERSH: The president has set a goal of doubling exports, but everybody else in the world has set a goal of expanding exports. Everybody can`t export their way out of their problems. How is it going to work?

KIRK: We can, it is work. And the one good thing is you know the president laid out that marker two years ago and remarkably we`re well on pace to meeting that. One of the things helping to drive our economic recovery is the reality that exports and only 13 percent of our GDP are contributing almost as much to our economic recovery as consumer spending.

GERSH: Well, U.S. trade representative and Mavericks fan Ron Kirk, thank you very much for your time.

KIRK: Huge Mavericks fan. Thank you.

GHARIB: And a U-turn today for one of the nation`s most powerful lobbies. AARP, which represents millions of older Americans said it is open to modest cuts in Social Security benefits for future recipients. The group has been a leading opponent of cutting benefits. But AARP now says it wants to limit any changes in benefits, while making sure the system remains solvent.

Well, Tom, it was a choppy week to be an understatement. And now investors have a weekend to think things over and start all over again on Monday.

HUDSON: Start all over again and of course always looking to Europe over the weekend, really, for the clues that we`re going to see on Monday. But it was quite a day today here, Susie. Let`s go ahead and roll with tonight`s "Market Focus." We had a mixed finish for the major indices for the second day in a row. Investors still trying to balance the threat of European government debt against the consistency of lower energy prices that we`ve seen over the past several sessions. Let`s start by updating where the S&P 500 is in relation back to its March low. There`s that March low that we had back in the spring. This remains an area of key technical support and so far, it is holding as we can see with the fractional rise we`ve got with in the S&P index. It bounced off that level. The market has held above that March low, so far optimistic.

The slide in oil prices meantime, here`s what the last 90 sessions in the front month crude oil contract in New York looked like. Crude here falling today another 2 percent. This is the lowest price that we`ve seen since February. Energy prices -- that may help the broad market lower prices, but it hurt energy stocks. Drilling company Nabors falling almost 4 percent. Oil producer Hess (NYSE: HES) dropping 1.5 percent. That`s a new 2011 low for Hess (NYSE: HES). And equipment company National Oilwell Varco shed just over 1 percent. These were the leading energy stock losers today in that sector.

Technology stocks also weak and check out Google (NASDAQ: GOOG) here. Continues to see money coming out of its share price, sinking another 3 percent today. This is Google (NASDAQ: GOOG)`s lowest price that we`ve seen in many months since September of last year. An analyst at investment banking firm Raymond James reports that paid online search spending is slowing down for the industry. Clearly that`s taken a chunk out of Google (NASDAQ: GOOG). Google (NASDAQ: GOOG)`s smartphone operating system Android is part of the challenge for Research in Motion (NASDAQ: RIMM)`s Blackberry. RIMM shares just got crushed today, very active trading. Look at this, 21.5 percent lower, losing more than a fifth of its value. This is just the past 30 sessions where you see the trend lower and then just falling off a shelf today. Volume exploding because of that sour outlook that we told you about last night. Let`s pull out to the past five years, showing this recent drop really in context and here it is over the past several months with RIMM, now in fact below the March of `09 low. Remember this is the low for the broader market. We`re seeing prices here in RIMM 27 3/4. We haven`t seen that since the fall of 2006. Now we do have an analysis of Research in Motion (NASDAQ: RIMM)`s chart on our website. Go to NBR on pbs.org.

A couple of other big tech stocks that are in the Dow Industrial index. Cisco dropping another half percent, just pennies above its most recent 52-week low. The company has struggled with disappointing guidance trying to restructure. Cisco is the worst Dow stock this year. Since January, we`ve got it down 25 percent.

Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) meantime the best Dow stock today with a 1.2 percent rally. It`s also though negative for the year as it continues to trend lower for tech. The worst stock sector this year, financials, not today though. Real estate service firm CB Richard Ellis jumping more than 4.5 percent. Tennessee-based bank First Horizon gaining almost 4 percent. And Zion bank out of Utah up about 3.5 percent, helping out the financials. According to the "Wall Street Journal," PNC Financial meantime is the winner in the bidding war for the U.S. retail operation of Royal Bank of Canada. No confirmation. Here`s PNC shares trending lower here, along with the rest of the financial sector, slipping almost 3 percent. Heavy volume, this is the lowest price of PNC since December.

The "Journal" also reports securities regulators are considering civil charges against credit rating agencies. Moody`s shares dropping 5 percent on this news. Parent company of Standard & Poor`s, McGraw-Hill falling 3.6 percent.

We saw a trio of new stocks going public this week, get you updated here, a couple of high profile issues. Bankrate.com sold its stock at $15 today for the first time, rising a tad. Internet radio provider Pandora Media started at $16. It`s below that IPO price tonight. And oil and nat gas services company Compressco Partners began at $20 and it slipped from there. That is tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Former Washington Mutual CEO Kerry Killinger and other top Wamu executives are in talks with the FDIC to settle a nearly $1 billion lawsuit filed against them. Killinger has until to the end of this month to respond to the FDIC`s complaint against him. Regulators allege Wamu executives took extreme risks with the bank`s mortgage portfolio, which led to the largest bank failure in U.S. history.

Meanwhile, another former bank executive is headed to prison for eight years. Catherine Kissick (ph) used to head a mortgage division at the now- defunct Colonial Bank. She learned her punishment today. Prosecutors say Kissick`s role in a $3 billion fraud scheme led to Colonial`s demise, as well as to Taylor Bean and Whitaker -- one of the nation`s largest private mortgage companies. Taylor Bean`s former chairman and owner Lee Farkas (ph) is due to be sentenced later this month.

HUDSON: Here`s what we`re watching for next week. Our scheduled Friday "Market Monitor" guest Alan Lancz. He`s editor of the "Lancz Letter." The Federal Reserve will be back in the spotlight. It begins a two-day meeting on Tuesday next week. Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke will hold a news conference on Wednesday. Monday on the program, creating jobs during challenging economic times. We talk to state leaders about what the role of government should be.

GHARIB: Food prices will likely head higher over the next decade. That`s what the United Nations and the Organization for Economic Corporation and Development are predicting. The reason - rising commodities prices and demand. The groups fear that higher food prices will hurt the world`s poor who already spend as much as 80 percent of their income on food.

HUDSON: The fight against Medicare and Medicaid fraud goes high tech next month. That`s when the Federal government begins using new software aimed at flagging would-be criminals before they get a check from Uncle Sam. Medicare has awarded a $77 million contract for the new system to defense giant Northrop Grumman (NYSE: NOC) and a group of companies. They`ll use technology that`s similar to that of banking and telecommunication companies to spot fraud.

Greece, jobs, housing. There is no shortage of worries for investors and that may be one reason to get more optimistic. So says tonight`s "Market Monitor." Bernie Schaeffer back with us, chairman of Schaeffer`s Investment Research, publisher of the "Option Advisor Market Letter." Always nice to see you Bernie. Welcome back.

BERNIE SCHAEFFER, CHMN., SCHAEFFER`S INVESTMENT RESEARCH: Thank you, Tom.

HUDSON: It was January when you were here last and you said that the market was in a disbelief rally. Investors just didn`t believe that stock prices deserved to move higher. We`re in essentially the same place in the market today than we were back in January. What about the market rally?

SCHAEFFER: Still in disbelief. Got another magazine cover from "Time" recently, June 20th dated, talking about what economic recovery question mark, still no major end close equity mutual funds. Something interesting right here and now is the market is at a point, all the major averages are flat for the year. Very often you find that when you reach a benchmark like that, just as we did in March, it is time for a rally. People look to come in at points like that.

HUDSON: One of the places that has fueled this move back to flat is the financial space. The financial stocks are always seen as market leading. It`s clearly led the market lower over the past six weeks. It`s the worst performing sector so far this year. Are you saying, if the market can move higher from here, that bank stocks will as well?

SCHAEFFER: I think the bank stocks are an interesting short. And an interesting put by, simply because you mentioned that people were looking at the bank stocks and people were quite bullish on the bank stocks. Analysts are still extremely bullish. There are big fund planners in there if the sector had not been able to get out of its own way.

HUDSON: So you are bearish on banks?

SCHAEFFER: I bearish. This is the slope of hope that sectors decline on until you get the capitulation stage. So I think there is still a good short trade shaping up in the banking sector even though I`m bullish on the overall market.

HUDSON: You are using options here to play the downside that you expect in banks looking at the XLF, ticker symbol for the I shares, financial select. Here is the options trade, buy January 2012 at the money puts, the option to sell, a bearish call. It profits if this exchange- traded fund falls. It has clearly fallen a lot already. And you are expecting it to what move into the single digits, perhaps?

SCHAEFFER: That would be a home run on this option trade but you know, even if you got a 25 percent decline, that would be a very nice gain. And it`s a good hedge for a sector that you might be bullish on.

HUDSON: So noted. You do like consumers and at least consumer stocks, specifically retail stocks. Here is the S&P retail exchange-traded fund, the XRT. You are looking at again January 2012 calls, a bullish call, an option to buy this exchange-traded fund. If the XRT moves up at the rallies, this option rallies in price as well. What`s fueling retail?

SCHAEFFER: What`s fueling the retail stocks is kind of the opposite of what the banking and financial stocks are having trouble with. The actual price action has been strong. Despite the fact that Wall Street is very skeptical on these stocks and so what that means is, this is the wall of worry that bullish sectors and markets climb. It means that sideline money is being drawn in reluctantly but steadily into sectors like retailers whose price action and earnings is positively surprising and potentially out of sectors like financial where the results are negatively surprising and the expectations are high.

HUDSON: That is your set-up for the next six months. Six months ago when you were here you had a couple of options plays. Let`s look how these have turned out. You were essentially bullish on the I shares Russell 2000 exchange- traded fund, August at the money calls. The option price though is down 43 percent as the exchange-traded fund essentially has gone nowhere. So time decay is what option traders call this. Do you still like this?

SCHAEFFER: Yes. And time decay versus leverage is the conundrum of making money in buying options.

HUDSON: Meantime this one was a big strikeout. You lost all your money with the June at the money calls for the iPath S&P 500, VIX exchange- traded note. Essentially you were looking for volatility as a hedge which has actually gone down in the last six months even though it has ticked up here lately in the past few weeks.

SCHAEFFER: Right. And I would rather hedge sector to sector as we are talking about today.

HUDSON: So noted. What about disclosures for these options?

SCHAEFFER: I don`t have positions in the XLF or XRT exchange-traded fund.

HUDSON: We`re going to catch up in six months. Nice to see you again.

SCHAEFFER: Great, pleasure.

HUDSON: Bernie Schaeffer, Schaeffer Investment Research.

GHARIB: And finally tonight, the author who got kids and parents reading together has something new, but it`s not a book. Harry Potter author JK Rowling will soon unveil her latest venture and all we know so far is that it`s called Pottermore and it won`t be a book. The site has few details, but links to a countdown clock marking the days and hours until the launch Tom and media watchers are speculating that the big announcement will be about some sort of online "Harry Potter" experience, perfect thing for you to do with your two boys.

HUDSON: I tell you. We`re not quite there yet for the Harry Potter books but we will be in just a short few years, Susie. That is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Friday night, June 17. Thanks for joining us. Have a great weekend, you as well Susie.

GHARIB: Same to you Tom and a happy Father`s Day to you and all the other fathers in our audience. I`m Susie Gharib. Hope to see all of you again next week.
