UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The ayes are 70. The nays are 30. The nomination is confirmed.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Ben Bernanke wins a second term as Fed chairman despite some harsh criticism from lawmakers.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: A look at what this vote means for the nation`s top banker tonight. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, January 28.

GHARIB: Good evening everyone. Ben Bernanke got the OK from the Senate today; he gets to keep his job. Tom as you know, there was plenty of drama and debate before the vote.

HUDSON: There sure was Susie and when the dust finally had settled on Capitol Hill, lawmakers did vote 70 to 30 to re-appoint Bernanke to another four years now as chairman of the Federal Reserve.

GHARIB: Tom, the controversy over Bernanke`s policies and what they mean for jobs, inflation and the economy won`t go away. He`s still under pressure. As Darren Gersh reports, many politicians will be watching Bernanke now more closely than ever.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Ben Bernanke`s supporters consider him the indispensable man of the financial crisis. As Federal Reserve chairman, Bernanke pumped more than $1 trillion into the banking system, hoping to prevent another great depression. Sometime this year Bernanke is expected to reverse course, raising interest rates and winding down many of the crisis programs he put in place. Rhode Island`s Jack Reed called that a delicate task and a good reason to give Bernanke a second term.

SEN. JACK REED, (D) RHODE ISLAND: We need someone that understands these programs and understands them not just theoretically, but literally from trial and error, understanding what worked, what didn`t work, what the consequences are.

GERSH: One consequence of waiting too long to take that money out of the banking system could be a burst of inflation. New Hampshire`s Judd Gregg said Bernanke won`t let that happen.

SEN. JUDD GREGG, (R) NEW HAMPSHIRE: As we all know, inflation is the cruelest tax of all. Because it devalues peoples savings and it undermines the productivity of a nation.

GERSH: Other conservatives argued Bernanke`s low interest rate policies created those very inflation risks. And Kentucky`s Jim Bunning reminded his colleagues of what he sees as the Bernanke Fed`s lasting legacy.

SEN. JIM BUNNING, (R) KENTUCKY: A vote for Ben Bernanke is a vote for bailouts. Chairman Bernanke has been in the middle of all the financial bailouts during the crisis.

GERSH: From the left, Democrats pushed the Fed to put Main Street ahead of Wall Street. And Rhode Island Senator Sheldon Whitehouse said it wasn`t just Bernanke who needed to change course.

SEN. SHELDON WHITEHOUSE, (D) RHODE ISLAND: The leaders of President Obama`s economic team must pivot from the necessary rescue of our major financial institutions to equally, if not more necessary, help to America`s families.

GERSH: But today`s confirmation vote was partly about reassuring investors on Wall Street. Some of Bernanke`s strongest supporters argued a no vote would undermine confidence just as the economy and financial markets are finding solid footing. Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

HUDSON: Let`s take a look at the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel for you. Tech stocks leading the way lower on Wall Street. Poor outlooks from Qualcomm and Motorola churned up new worries about the economy. At the close, there it is, the Dow Industrials down 115 points, the NASDAQ down 42 and the S&P 500 off nearly 13. All three now are at new lows for the year.

Results from Microsoft may help set the tone for tomorrow`s trading. The software giant turning in strong fiscal second quarter results with earnings up 60 percent on strong demand for Windows 7. Meanwhile online, amazon.com, huge profits, up 71 percent on robust holiday sales. The company says it`s upbeat about its Kindle e-reader, even with Apple`s iPad launch. We`ll have more specifics on Amazon and Apple coming up in tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Something different at Ford, the auto maker says it made money last year. In fact, it`s the first full year profit since 2005. Ford earned almost $3 billion last year, reversing a loss of more than $14 billion in 2008. CEO Alan Mulally expects the profit streak to continue over the next two years, at least before taxes. Driving those profits, sales of Ford`s popular Fusion cars and a turnaround in its finance business. Ford also hopes to take advantage of a competitor`s weakness and win over Toyota buyers. It`s offering $1,000 to customers trading in a late-model Toyota.

HUDSON: As for Toyota tonight, it is waiting for Federal safety regulators to sign off on the fix for its gas pedal problems. With the recall growing, the auto maker known for quality faces some tough questions. Jeffrey Liker is an engineering professor at the University of Michigan and author of the book "The Toyota Way." Professor, welcome to NBR. Has Toyota lost its way with this six million vehicle recall?

JEFFREY LIKER, PROFESSOR, UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN: I don`t think so. Six million sounds like six million problems, but it`s actually two problems that they`ve been able to identify, a problem with carpets when they are loose and a problem with sticky pedals after a few years that has happened in a relatively small number of cars. So I don`t think you could say that. n my experience looking, visiting their plants, visiting their engineering offices, their quality is actually better than ever. For example, 10 JD Power awards for initial quality, the most of any auto maker last year.

HUDSON: But this is certainly front and center in most consumers and investors` minds. Is the recall and how Toyota has been handling it here do you think any indication that the culture of quality perhaps is changing on the edges?

LIKER: I think it`s certainly an indication about the interest of the press and the Internet and how quickly news gets blown up so that you forget it is the pedal and it`s carpet and it becomes the whole company. So I think that gives a very unrealistic impression of what is happening within Toyota.

HUDSON: But certainly isn`t this representative of what Toyota does, which is build cars and perhaps there is nothing more central to a car other than its gas pedal?

LIKER: The gas pedal works in almost every case but after a few years it gets sticky. And it feels sort of awkward. So that also happens in every other car in the world in certain cases. It is not unique to Toyota, but they did find that there is a particular material and a little piece of metal that interacts with moisture and one supplier used that particular material and that is generating all the millions of recalls. It is not certainly indicative of quality in the company. It is not really evidence that...

HUDSON: You`ve studied Toyota for years. You visited plants both in the United States and globally. How prepared do you think the company is to deal with this size of recall, both from the perspective of customers and drivers but as well as shareholders.

LIKER: Well, actually they are probably more prepared than before the recession. One of the things Toyota did in the recession was to keep all their people employed, train them, solve quality problems in the plant. They launched new vehicles. They move vehicles from plant to plant so they are probably more flexible and more prepared than they have ever been before.

HUDSON: In 2001 as you know, Toyota set out to become the world`s biggest auto maker. It did succeed. Do you think that appetite for growth played any role in this recall at all? Those questions are being asked now, I imagine.

LIKER: I know those questions are being asked, again, I think by uninformed people that aren`t realizing this is a supplier and a pedal. And it`s a carpet that if it is not fastened down causes a problem. I don`t know what that tells you about the company, when a company is consistently winning quality awards from JD Power, consistently at the tops of consumer reports.

HUDSON: With all those --

LIKER: The measures are getting better every year.

HUDSON: So with all those awards recognized, why do you think Toyota took the step to actually issue a massive recall as opposed to just deal with these problems as they came in?

LIKER: If you have a pedal, yeah, if you have a pedal that can stick and you meet with NTSA and you decide a recall --

HUDSON: NTSA is the National Transportation Safety Administration.

LIKER: The national, yes, exactly and they meet and they don`t know which of those other cars has that problem. They have no way of knowing. It could be one, it could be 10, it could be 50. So they obviously have to take action. And that`s also the responsible thing to do. But that doesn`t tell you anything about what is going on in their Georgetown, Kentucky plant or the Indiana plant or their engineering office. It is still this one problem that the pedal in one plant that made, in a supplier plant and the designed decision was made 10 years ago.

HUDSON: We have to leave it there. We appreciate you answering questions.

LIKER: You have to go back 10 years.

HUDSON: There we go. Jeffrey Liker along with us, University of Michigan professor, author of "The Toyota Way."

GHARIB: Still ahead, how Toyota is responding to customers on the web. And when it comes to social networking, what your company needs to know about crisis management.

HUDSON: Continuing just a bit with Toyota, it is in tonight`s "Market Focus." With the recall expanding, the company that makes the gas pedal assemblies the professor referred to at the heart of this problem says don`t blame it. That didn`t necessarily help the shares of the company. CTS (CTS), we talked about it last night, again here, after staging a bit of a recovery on Wednesday, today another tough day as you can see, usually about 100,000 CTS shares trade hands. Today more than a million and a half traded and the company said Toyota (TM) is responsible for the bad pedal design, not it. Meantime, CTS says it`s adding extra shifts at three of its factories to make replacement parts. And the company says none of the pedals it sends to Toyota are used by other auto makers. Competing supplier Denso already is Toyota`s biggest parts maker. A spokeswoman tells NBR their Toyota pedals are made in Japan and that it will support Toyota as much as possible, but she would not be specific.

Earlier we did mention today`s big tech earnings from Microsoft (MSFT) and Amazon (AMZN). Let`s take a look at some of the details here. To get the $0.74 a share profit last quarter that you see from Microsoft, it added in deferred revenue. This all relates to the October release of its Windows 7. It sold the software to computer makers two quarters ago before the software was officially released. Those sales are now included in this quarterly report. After hours, Microsoft stock up about $0.40 after dropping almost 2 percent on double normal volume.

Amazon shares certainly catching a bit after the close, up $3 at one point, hitting close to $130 a share, up almost $3 ahead of these results. Santa very kind to amazon.com, a big blow away quarter here. It`s not expected to stop. The company predicts sales to be at least 32 percent higher this quarter. Barclays thinks that Amazon`s Kindle will remain hot even with the new iPad from Apple.

Some of the big movers in the world of mobile phones are moving in different directions. On the downside, Qualcomm (QCOM) after lowering its sales forecast, the stock dropping 14 percent, very active, almost 10 times volume. Motorola (MOT) stock meantime hitting fresh six month lows tonight. The fourth quarter profit not enough to impress buyers because a warning came. Fewer devices from Motorola will be shipped this quarter. The biggest competitor, Nokia (NOK) saw its stock hit three-month highs on six times normal volume. Better than expected results and a bigger slice of the cell phone market helping push shares of Nokia higher.

Let`s catching up on a couple or rather a trio of the Dow components that did report results today, pushing the market around. Pampers maker P&G, Procter & Gamble (PG) did its best to put some green on the board. It was the biggest percentage gainer today, up almost 2 percent for the Dow. Profits beat the Street, thanks in part to price cuts as well as higher priced new products.

Post-it note maker 3M (MMM) was able to show growing profits, pushed up its prediction for the year, not enough though for the stock. Take a look. The shares wane on the index slipping to an early December low.

Let me tell you quickly about AT&T (T) shares, down by only $0.06 in the day, this after matching estimates thanks to its wireless business certainly with Apple`s iPhone.

And a former Dow component turned in a big day of buying. Eastman Kodak (EK), take a look at the stock, 54 million shares, nine times average and at a six-month high, close to a six-month high, its highest price at least since September. Now the Dow Industrials only 120 points above 10,000. Investors here unimpressed with earnings and earnings will continue to be in the "Market Focus."

GHARIB: More on the Toyota recall, as we know, it`s a big story for the news media. But it`s also a big topic of discussion on social media. Toyota has an active social networking presence on Facebook, Twitter and Youtube. It`s answering customer concerns on those sites and on its own web page it has a list of frequently asked questions and answers. This kind of proactive response is exactly what the doctor ordered, according to Scott Gurvey`s guide to social networking. Scott wraps up his series tonight with a look at how businesses should approach these new media platforms.

SCOTT GURVEY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: If you think the people around you spend a lot of time on social networking sites, you are probably right. And if you are a business hoping to expand through social networking, digital strategy guru Stephanie Agresta says you should plan on making it a part of your regular routine.

STEPHANIE AGRESTA, VP DIGITAL STRATEGY, PORTER NOVELLI: As a business, if you`re making the investment to be there, then you need to be there consistently. It`s not something you can jump into, post, let days go by and then post again. Your customers need to know that you are really committed to the medium.

GURVEY: So, our first take-away tonight is devote time. Nicole Romagnoll spends an hour each day maintaining her pet care company`s Facebook page.

NICOLE ROMAGNOLL, FETCH! PET CARE OF STATEN ISLAND: It`s not work for me. It`s fun. You`re socializing. It`s exciting when you post a picture of a new client and then you get people commenting underneath about how cute. I look forward to seeing that stuff so when I want a break from my day, I`ll go on to my fan page.

GURVEY: One thing to be aware of with social networking is a multiplier effect. Columbia Professor Sree Sreenivasan says it`s both a blessing and a curse.

SREE SREENIVASAN, DIGITAL MEDIA PROFESSOR, COLUMBIA UNIV.: The power of twitter is really in the re-tweet. As in, somebody takes the post you made and then re-tweets it and sends it out. So instead of someone just saying something at the water cooler they`re saying it at the digital water cooler which has this effect of this echo that can make things that are not true seem true and things that are true, they can amplify it in a good way or in a bad way.

GURVEY: Lev Ekster says knowing how quickly a negative comment about his cupcake company can spread keeps everyone on their toes.

LEV EKSTER, FOUNDER, CUPCAKESTOP.COM: All it takes is one dissatisfied customer to send a tweet about you to really hurt the business, so that`s why we try so hard. And we know we have this immense exposure on Twitter now with 9,000 people following us, so it`s important to maintain quality and make sure all those 9,000 people are pleased with you.

GURVEY: Which brings us to our final take-away. Don`t panic. If you get a complaint, social media adviser Jennifer Jacobson says, meet it head on.

JENNIFER JACOBSON, AUTHOR & SOCIAL MEDIA EXPERT: It`s probably not that they just don`t like you and want to say bad things about your business. They probably have a legitimate concern. So step back. Sort of take the emotion out of it and really look at what it is they`re saying and address it honestly. Because if you can have that kind of conversation even over Twitter, your other customers that are following you are going to see that and they`re going to see the tact and the skill and the sincerity with which you addressed that person`s complaint or issue. And hopefully they will respect that.

GURVEY: Our guide to social networking doesn`t end here. There`s more on our web site, NBR on pbs.org and we hope the next chapter in the guide will be written by you. Add your comments and tips for businesses going online to our blog and we`ll keep the dialogue going. Scott Gurvey, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: Here`s what we`re watching for tomorrow. We`ll see earnings from Chevron, Fortune Brands, Honeywell and Mattel. And we also get our first look at how the economy did in the final three months of last year. The prediction? Up over 4 percent. And, our Friday "Market Monitor" guest says the economic recovery is the real deal. He`s John Dorfman, chairman of Thunderstorm Capital looking for double digit growth in the year 2010.

GHARIB: Case dismissed against Broadcom founder Henry Nicholas. A Federal judge today threw out drug charges and two civil cases against the former CEO. He had faced the possibility of decades in prison. Last month, Nicholas was cleared of insider trading charges after the judge accused prosecutors of misconduct. Lawyers for the SEC still plan to re- file a lawsuit related to those charges.

HUDSON: If you`re an at-risk homeowner and want help modifying your mortgage from the government, you`ll have to prove your income up front with recent pay stubs and tax returns. Previously, borrowers could provide their income verbally and supply documentation later. That caused problems because many homeowners never got around to doing it. Out of 900,000 trial modifications, only 7 percent or 66,000 have become permanent. The paperwork change begins June 1st.

GHARIB: As we said, Ben Bernanke will be running the Fed for the next four years. But he might not have as much free reign this time around. Some members of Congress want to audit the Fed`s activities. Our commentator tonight thinks that`s a bad idea and he ought to know. He`s Alan Blinder, former vice chair of the Fed and professor of economics at Princeton.

ALAN BLINDER, ECONOMICS PROFESSOR, PRINCETON UNIVERSITY: Do you ever get the feeling that this country is over-lawyered? Well, here`s another example. Ron Paul, the libertarian congressman who wants to abolish the Federal Reserve, has long promoted a first step in that direction. The so- called Paul bill would subject the Fed`s monetary policy decisions to GAO audits. Like most economists, I find the idea, well, appalling. But I breathed a sigh of relief when a modified version was appended to the House`s financial reform bill late last year. The Paul-Grayson amendment added what I thought was an important clause. Let me read it to you. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed as interference in or dictation of monetary policy to the Federal Reserve System by the Congress or the GAO.

That sounds like a strong affirmation of the Fed`s independence, right? I certainly read it that way and so did my students. Then I talked to a lawyer. So put on your lawyers glasses and read it again Nothing in this subsection shall be construed as interference and so on. Read literally, the sentence does not instruct Congress to keep its nose out of monetary policy. Instead, it asserts that the proposed law does not interfere with monetary policy even if you think it does. Orwell`s big brother would have been proud. He gave us war is peace, freedom is slavery. Now the House thought police give us interference is not interference. Ladies and gentlemen of the House, could we please fix this? I`m Alan Blinder.

HUDSON: Finally tonight, when it comes to music, what`s old is now new. Vinyl records once considered obsolete are making a big comeback. Jeff Yastine reports tonight, that`s music to the ears of many fans.

JEFF YASTINE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: A busy afternoon at Sweat Records. Amid the re-stocking of vegetarian jerky treats, you`ll find other hints of what`s really for sale here. Record adapters? What are those? And along one side of the store, a mother load of vinyl. These are new pressings, not used records. Lauren Reskin presides over this vinyl paradise.

LAUREN RESKIN OWNER, SWEAT RECORDS: Most people are really surprised when they come in, you guys sell records? We get that from older folks are most surprised and then young kids come in and they`re just like ooh vinyl. It`s neat that the perspectives are kind of changing on that.

YASTINE: Some of the albums are iconic, reissues of classic Beatles, Beach Boys, Miles Davis. But right alongside those, you`ll find new releases, from bands you`ve likely never heard of, yet. Reskin says vinyl and digital can peacefully co-exist. In many cases, if you buy a vinyl record, you get the digital download for free. And for the iPod generation, those records come with a new appreciation of cover art.

RESKIN: Like this, on CD it looks like a big jumble of just stuff. But when you blow it up this big, there`s a street scene and some cool graphics and this one comes with a 32-page booklet, liner notes and a comic book and graffiti and downloads. That`s a lot more bang for your buck than just a normal CD.

YASTINE: Vinyl record sales have soared, nearly tripling to 2.5 million records in the last three years. Not bad for a format long declared dead. And here is one of the few places where vinyl records are still made. Linford Ellis is one of the few engineers who still knows how to turn raw vinyl into music. There are only a dozen pressing plants still operating in the U.S., half of what existed 20 years ago.

LINFORD ELLIS, PLANT MANAGER, ALPHA MUSIC MFG.: And most of those people now, they can`t do this job anymore. They`ve forgotten what they`ve learned, so the few people around, the few pressing plants that are around, are still going. We`re like gold dust.

YASTINE: To give you a sense of how much the vinyl record business has taken off, this machine pumps out about 800 vinyl records a day. This is actually a 45 but with a small hole. But now they have a second machine, this one here. It`s also pumping out 800 records as well. Business is so good these days that Alpha is bringing in a third, a fourth and a fifth machine. But these machines are so old that they`re having to scrounge for parts to get them up and running again. That`s a good problem to have, if you`re Jeffrey Collins, CEO of Alpha Music Manufacturing. He`s as surprised as anyone about vinyl`s resurgence.

JEFFREY COLLINS, CEO, ALPHA MUSIC MFG.: It`s exciting. I didn`t think that vinyl was going to continue and last as long as it did. I don`t think vinyl will ever die.

YASTINE: Not everyone agrees. Some think it`s a fad or a love of all things retro. Then again, back at Sweat Records...

RESKIN: In the first year we were around, we expanded our vinyl immensely. And in that first year is when I realized we`re going to sell more vinyl than I anticipated.

YASTINE: That was five years ago. And vinyl, like Reskin`s store is still going strong. Jeff Yastine, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Miami.

HUDSON: And that is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Thursday, January 28. I`m Tom Hudson. Good night to everybody and good night to you too, Susie.

GHARIB: See you tomorrow Tom. I`m Susie Gharib. Good night everyone, hope to see all of you again tomorrow night right here.

END

urn:contentItem:5KRW-K151-DY0W-44JC-00000-00Nightly Business Report2012-12-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:43ZLexisNexisNightly Business ReportLanhamFULL TEXT

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Good evening. I'm Tom Hudson.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Hi, Tom. It's great to be here. Good evening everyone. I'm Susie Gharib.

HUDSON: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) says it will bring some computer production back to the United States, but why has the stock dropped more than 20 percent this fall?

GHARIB: The fiscal cliff moves to the kitchen table. President Obama visits a Virginia family and tells them how the cliff could impact their budget.

HUDSON: And a very special conversation tonight with Paul Kangas. NBR's founding co-anchor joins us to answer your questions.

GHARIB: We have that and more right here tonight on NBR.

HUDSON: Millions and millions of iPhones, iPads and Mac computers from Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) brag they were designed in California, but admit they were built in China. Next year, some of those Macs will be built in the U.S. too. CEO Tim Cook made the pledge to return to U.S. manufacturing in two media interviews. It marks a return for Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) which transferred most of its technology building to Asia more than a decade ago. It's more of a symbolic move though than a big financial investment. After all, Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) spends more than $9 billion a year on manufacturing and the U.S. commitment is expected to be about $100 million or 1 percent of its global factory investments. Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) didn't say where in the U.S. the line of Mac computers would be built or how many jobs might be included. Now the return of Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) to U.S. manufacturing comes as shareholders have experienced a very rocky ride in the past few months. The stock is down 22 percent from its all-time high in September. Suzanne Pratt reports.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: A peak inside this Manhattan Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) store and it looks like everything is a- OK, plenty of customers, plenty of purchases. So why has the shine come off Apple's shares? Within a word, actually two, profit-taking.

BRIAN COSTELLO, SR. EQUITY ANALYST, MORNINGSTAR: I think the biggest reason for the selling going back to when it was priced $700 in September has been pure profit-taking. If you look from the beginning of the year to September, the stock was up 74 percent. So I think you had some natural profit-taking.

PRATT: But this isn't ordinary year-end selling by institutions looking to record nice numbers. This supposedly is fiscal cliff related selling as shareholders worry that capital gains tax rates will be higher next year. Still, financial planner Sharon Appelman says selling stock solely for tax reasons isn't the best idea.

SHARON APPELMAN, FINANCIAL PLANNER: I definitely think it's a legitimate concern and can be an opportunity. And I would say if somebody was interested in reducing a position anyway, that can certainly be a great time to do it. You know, why pay higher taxes in a few months time when you can pay a lower tax now?

PRATT: And some analysts say, before unloading the shares, consider that fundamentals for Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) haven't really changed. Sure, revenue growth may slow and there are worries the tech giant will have trouble fending off competition from increasingly popular Android products. But to some analysts, the shares look especially cheap today, especially considering their move south since the September high.

COSTELLO: We think the smart phone trend is still in the early to middle innings. It is not in the late innings yet. So we think, to the extent that Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) can maintain its share of the premium smart phone market, we think they'll do quite well. You throw the iPad on top of it and how it's cannibalizing PCs, that's another great growth driver.

PRATT: It is worth noting that Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) shares are still up more than 30 percent this year. Even with more tax-related selling, it will be tough to erase all of those profits in the next few weeks. Suzanne Pratt, NBR, New York.

GHARIB: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) shares rose more than 1.5 percent today and that gave a boost to stocks. Also better than expected job news encouraged investors. New claims for jobless benefits fell by 25,000 in the week ending December 1 to a lower than expected 370,000 requests and that could be a good sign for the November jobs report that comes out tomorrow and we'll have more on that in just a moment. Separately, American companies announced 57,000 job cuts in November. That's accord to employment firm Challenger, Gray and Christmas, says that's 20 percent higher from October's levels. On Wall Street today, the Dow rose 39 points, the NASDAQ added 15, the S&P up nearly five.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: I'm Erika Miller in New York. Coming up tonight, we'll talk to the CEO of kitchen store Sur la Table and get his outlook for holiday sales.

HUDSON: Lots of theatrics today, but few visible signs of progress in Washington towards a fix for the fiscal cliff. The only hopeful sign is that Republicans and Democrats are talking privately again. There remains a lot of work ahead certainly including what to do about the nation's debt limit. Washington will hit its borrowing limit early next year. Darren Gersh has the latest.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Sitting around the kitchen table with a middle class family in Virginia, the president once again pressed for Congress to avoid the fiscal cliff.

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If this family has a couple of thousand dollars less to spend, that translates into $200 billion of less consumer spending next year. And that's bad for businesses, large and small.

GERSH: Behind the scenes, the two sides are talking again. But there was no progress in public. Senators today fought over the debt limit and ended up deadlocked over a bill to allow the president to automatically increase borrowing.

SEN. MITCH McCONNELL, MINORITY LEADER: He's shown what he is really after is assuming unprecedented power to spend taxpayer dollars without any limit at all.

GERSH: If the debt limit isn't raised, the country can't pay for the spending Congress has already approved. And economists say the nation pays a high price for this kind of brinkmanship.

MARK ZANDI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY'S ANALYTICS: Business people aren't going to engage unless they have clarity with respect to this thing.

GERSH: But few insiders expect to find much clarity from Washington in the coming weeks. Darren Gersh, NBR, Washington.

GHARIB: Investors will be searching for more clarity on those fiscal cliff talks and they will also be studying tomorrow's important jobs report. But Josh Feinman says the November numbers won't give an accurate picture of the labor market. He's chief economist at DB Advisors. Hi, Josh, so you're talking about distortions in that report. Tell us more.

JOSH FEINMAN, CHIEF GLOBAL ECONOMIST, DB ADVISORS: Yes, hi, Susie. I think that the hurricane Sandy may distort the numbers. We've seen it in some of the other high frequency data in the last couple of weeks. Keep in mind tomorrow's labor market report will report on a snapshot of the labor market that was taken in the middle of last month. And that's when the hurricane and its aftermath were having their effects.

GHARIB: So the consensus numbers from a survey of economists, they're expecting American businesses added 110,000 jobs to their payroll. Their unemployment rate staying around 7.9 percent. Does that sit right with you? Is that what you are seeing?

FEINMAN: Probably somewhere around that, maybe a little less. One of the problems is it is hard to gauge exactly what the impact of the storm will have. We know it's transitory but it's hard to say exactly how much numerically it will subtract. The thing is, if the number comes in lower than that I think a lot of people will say oh, it was probably the effect of the hurricane and they'll wait until the following month to see what kind of a rebound we get.

GHARIB: Let's talk a little bit about what we can expect from the job market going forward. I don't know if you saw Alan Blinder's op/ed piece in "The Wall Street Journal." The former Fed governor saying that if we go over the fiscal cliff, the unemployment rate will jump to 11 percent because we'll be a recession and customarily when you are in a recession, the unemployment rate goes up 3 percentage points. Does that sound right to you? And if that is the case, what does this mean for consumers and for businesses?

FEINMAN: Well, it would be seriously bad news. But I think what is important is not just whether we go over the cliff but how long we stay over there. I mean if it turns out that they need a couple more days to hammer out an accord, I don't think that's going to have a big lasting effect. But if we go over the cliff and all those spending cuts and all those tax hikes go into effect and stay in effect for the whole year, then you would be talking about a very high likelihood of a recession and a rising unemployment, a substantial rise, we can quibble about how much. But it would be seriously bad news for consumers and businesses.

GHARIB: As you know Josh, the Federal Reserve is going to be meeting next week on Tuesday. Certainly this is all going to be a topic around the table. Is there a role for the Federal Reserve in this fiscal cliff back and forth?

FEINMAN: There really isn't a direct role that they can play. This is fiscal policy. The Fed does not make fiscal policy. It makes monetary policy. I think Chairman Bernanke and others have been very clear to stay out of the battle that has to be resolved by the Congress and the administration. Look, I think at the end of the day, they are going to reach some sort of an accord to avert the most draconian aspects of the fiscal cliff. Maybe the 11th, or 12th or maybe even the 13th hour, but I think they are going to reach that because I think they recognize that the consequences of not doing so are so severe.

GHARIB: But let's face it, that even if there is a deal, we're talking about an economy that is going to have to deal with people having higher taxes and dealing with spending cuts. What are you projecting for 2013 real quickly? We have a little time left, for economic growth and unemployment.

FEINMAN: Sure. I think the economy is going to be facing some fiscal drag from the Federal side, but if it is phased in slowly, it's not really austere and abrupt, I think it can handle it because I think the private sector is healing and I'm looking for some improvement in growth by the second half of the year provided that we don't hit a landmine here on the fiscal side.

GHARIB: All right, Josh, thanks so much, great talking with you. We've been speaking with Josh Feinman of DB Advisors.

HUDSON: Nearly a month and a half after super storm Sandy wreaked havoc along the New Jersey shore, President Obama met today with Governor Chris Christie at the White House. The topic was Federal aid for storm recovery. The president is expected to ask Congress for about $50 billion in additional emergency help. Ruben Ramirez is in Seaside Heights, New Jersey tonight, where business owners are still trying to recover. Ruben?

RUBEN RAMIREZ, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Thanks, Tom. Yes, nearly six weeks after super storm Sandy devastated this barrier island off the coast of New Jersey, there's still a curfew in place. A lot of the traffic you see behind me is a lot of those longtime residents from the island and business owners who have been going back day in and day out, trying to recover and repair whatever's left. Some of those business owners we had a chance to speak to today. They say they'll reopen come next summer. You've been in business 33 years. Have you seen this sort of devastation before?

SAM HAMMER, OWNER, CRAB's CLAW INN: No, nothing like this. We -- that's the reason we stayed because they were explaining that there was going to be a terrible storm. But we, of this magnitude we had no idea. This is just like -- hard to believe.

RAMIREZ: Here we are almost six weeks after the storm hit. How soon until you get the business open and up and running again?

JIM BOEKHOLT, OWNER, BEN FRANKLIN: There's a few problems -- electrical and structural. But hopefully in the next maybe two months, we might be able to get open again. But definitely we will be open for the summer season.

RAMIREZ: Tom, some of those small business owners we spoke to say they didn't have flood insurance because they say the summer season is short here and the insurance is just too expensive. Tom.

HUDSON: Thanks, Ruben. You'll have more from Seaside Heights tomorrow. We have more on how insurance companies manage risk when it comes to natural disasters Learn about the modeling on our web site, nbr.com. Look for that nbr-u tab.

GHARIB: Americans were feeling a little richer recently, thanks to gains in real estate and the stock market. The Federal Reserve said today that household net worth rose to nearly $65 trillion between July and September. That's up nearly $2 trillion from the previous quarter. Net worth is total assets, like homes and stock portfolios, minus liabilities like mortgages and credit card debt. That wealth effect could make consumers feel more comfortable about shopping this holiday season. There are still 20 days to go before Christmas and the rush is on. Toys are always popular items of course, but there's one category that's expected to do even better and no, it's not electronics. Erika Miller reports.

MILLER: For many families, the holidays are all about the home. Few retailers know that better than Sur la Table, a 104-store chain selling kitchenware and tabletop items. CEO Jack Schwefel says sales are off to a strong start, and credits changing American values.

JACK SCHWEFEL, PRES & CEO, SUR LA TABLE: I think Americans are realizing the importance of the family meal, where people get together. No matter how crazy the day is, you can have that moment every day where it becomes the most important moment of the day and you share it with the people you love the most.

MILLER: Unlike many retailers, Sur la Table says it hasn't had a problem with showrooming this holiday season. That's when people come in to browse, but purchase cheaper versions online. Part of the reason is that 40 percent of the store's products are exclusive.

SCHWEFEL: One of the things that we are most proud of is the fact that we still import more product from Europe than we do from China. So you are talking about artisan product, product that has a story to it, that's special. You just don't see that in retailing in America.

MILLER: Stores like Sur la Table are expected to be one of the few bright spots in an otherwise lackluster holiday season. In fact, some analyst think home goods will be hotter than toys this holiday year. IBM projects home goods will see the strongest sales growth this year, up over 6 percent. That's far more than toys and electronics.

JILL PUFERI, GLOBAL RETAIL LEADER, IBM: You might ask yourself, why home, right? And we think home is up because of a lot of things -- things like the changing demographic of the home itself. There's one stat that says 41 percent of those between 25 and 29 are living back at home.

MILLER: But there also a second reason.

PUFERI: We think that this holiday people are buying what they need versus what they want.

MILLER: Which had me wondering what's on Jack Schwefel's wish list this holiday season. It wasn't this $5,500 coffee maker.

SCHWEFEL: There are some new knives in our store that I'm actually pretty excited about, so probably those. They're cutting board material is actually used in the handle of the knives.

MILLER: And there's no denying it will look good sur la table during the holidays. Erika Miller, NBR, New York.

GHARIB: I know what's on your wish list. A lot of people are buying new housewares. You love cooking.

HUDSON: I do love cooking. Listen I think is great that the house goods category is seeing some good growth here. It says that there is a lot of confidence in the housing market number one. But let's face it, just because it's home goods doesn't mean it's cheap Susie or inexpensive. A $5500 coffeemaker, some of these home appliance blenders can be $500.

GHARIB: If you are looking for discounts Tom, now there is green Monday. We have black Friday. We've had cyber Monday. Green Monday is the second Monday in December and that's when there is a lots of discounts online. So it will be good for consumers.

HUDSON: We've been talking a lot about the fiscal cliff, but I think there is the holiday cliff almost every year which is that game of chicken between stores. Are they going have to discount as we get closer to the holidays or are consumers, shoppers going to spend the money that the stores are asking for right now? Clearly another indication that stores perhaps may be getting a little bit nervous now.

GHARIB: Speaking of green, there was some green on Wall Street today.

HUDSON: There was some buying on Wall Street. Let's take a look at our "Market Focus" here Susie and we saw some better than expected data on first-time unemployment claims leading to a bit of a choppy start for the S&P 500. After Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) went positive in the 10:00 a.m. Eastern time hour, so did the index. Tech stocks turned solidly higher, so did the market, finishing up a third of a percent. Trading volume still moderate, 616 million shares on the big board, just over 1.7 trading on the NASDAQ.

It was the tech sector that led the way, up 0.8 of a percent. Consumer discretionary sector added 0.6 of 1 percent on the session. Now the big tech names in the Dow industrials weren't left out in the rally. Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) had the biggest percentage gains of the Dow 30 stocks. Shares of Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) up 1.6 percent. The CEO said the company could manufacture semiconductors for other chip makers quote, for the right types of products, end quote. So, queue the rumors today that hint about maybe Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) possibly making chips for Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL).

How about Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO) Systems moving up 1.4 percent. The move takes Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO) to its highest price since September. The top tech sector stock was Akamai Technologies (NASDAQ:AKAM). It helps speed up and manage online content and traffic. A new partnership announced today with AT&T (NYSE:T) led to the rally. Shares jumping 10 percent on heavy volume. Analysts say the deal turns AT&T (NYSE:T) from a competitor to Akamai's customer, eliminating rival business for Akamai.

On the consumer side, Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX) red hot. The company said it will pay more taxes in Britain in the next two years. Yesterday, it also announced plans to open at least 1,500 new stores in the U.S. over the next five years. Shares of SBUX jumping 5.7 percent. Volume tripled today with the stock closing tonight at five-month highs.

How about tax prep giant H&R Block (NYSE:HRB)? It sits at a new 52- week high tonight. It lost less money than feared last quarter. That was seen as good news. H&R Block (NYSE:HRB) has been cutting costs to focus on its core tax preparation business, especially drilling down to the digital tax prep business.

Even satellite radio operator Sirius/XM radio can't resist returning some cash to shareholders this season. It announced a one-time dividend of a nickel per share and a $2 billion stock buyback plan. Sirius shares are consistently among the most actively traded issues on the NASDAQ. Volume was very heavy as you'd expect today. The stock didn't move a whole lot though, up just $0.02. But there was a bigger stock move in Liberty Media Capital. Why Liberty Media? Well, it's the biggest shareholder of Sirius/XM stock. It stands to get $160 million thanks to the special dividend.

Online social gaming company Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) has struggled to repeat the success of its Farmville game. It's going after a gaming license now in Nevada. Don't look it on the strip though. It wants customers to use real money, bet real money on Internet poker. Shares rallying 7.1 percent, volume doubled. Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) has lost more than 70 percent of its value since becoming a publicly traded company.

All of the five most actively traded exchange-traded products were higher with the emerging markets fund up the most, up 0.8 of a percent. And that is tonight's "Market Focus."

GHARIB: And also with some market news, one of the hedge funds embroiled in the FBI's crackdown on insider trading is closing its doors. Diamondback Capital Management is shutting down and that's after clients pulled more than half a billion dollars from the fund. Federal agents raided the Connecticut firm two years ago as part of a nation-wide sweep that resulted in the arrest of one of the firm's former portfolio managers on insider trading charges. Since then, Diamondback's assets have dwindled to just over $1.5 billion, down from $5 billion.

GHARIB: Our viewers have been waiting and he's finally here. Paul Kangas, NBR co-founding anchor. Welcome home, it's so nice to have you back here.

PAUL KANGAS, NBR CO-FOUNDING ANCHOR: Well, it is like home and it's great to hear that I'm still welcome.

GHARIB: Actually, speaking of welcome. We got -- Tom and I got so many viewer questions for you and comments saying that they want to hear from the Walter Cronkite of financial news. A little bit of your wisdom in these confusing time, right, Tom.

HUDSON: Absolutely there is so much going on in the market and you've seen so much market cycles. We got a lot to talk about, but what we have got to ask ,what do you make of the stock market today?

KANGAS: It's sort of a stop and go affair. We get good news one day, better building permits and building news and on that front. And inflation is down a little bit. And then the next day it's all countered by new uprisings in Egypt and one thing or another. So the market tries to step higher and is countered by bad news. So stop and go all the way.

HUDSON: We got a great question from Eric P. Edson. You saw the Dow Industrials move from 1,000 to over 10,000 in your career. He asks, will the Dow Jones see 8,000 or 18,000 first?

KANGAS: Well, there's not that much volatility but it could see both in the same year. But I intend, I'm actually a little on the bullish bias because corporations continue to make money and the American people are basically optimistic. And a lot of stocks are under priced, particularly blue chips even though the Dow Industrial Average has more than doubled since 2009. But there's a reason for that and that's good earnings and that's good dividends.

GHARIB: Well, there's a lot of questions about if that is going to continue. And one of our viewers has a question for you about the fiscal cliff. You know all about the back and forth and the drama about the fiscal cliff and Delores Kile wants your thoughts on where do you stand on this whole fiscal cliff? How can it play out?

KANGAS: Congress better get off its duff and do something. And I think that finally the pressure is going to be enough (ph). But they always do it right to the last, you know, minute. But I think it's got to happen or they're going to be ousted from their hallowed political seats.

HUDSON: You could argue in the three years you've been away from the NBR anchor desk Congress hasn't done a whole heck of a lot to address the fiscal situation.

KANGAS: No it's just ridiculous. I mean these are our elected representatives and they have got to pay a little more attention to those that got them in the office. And they're arguing amongst themselves without much care about the people they represent.

HUDSON: A lot of those folks are retirees, we do have a question about retirement from Anita asking what is the investing or financial planning lesson Paul uses most during retirement?

KANGAS: Well, the number one is hope I can live my life to the last and still have enough capital to keep me going. And a lot of investors are running up against the same thing. They're running out of capital because yields are so low in the bond market; money markets are yielding practically nothing. So they have to chip into their base capital and that's hurtful. So what I am doing is looking for blue chip stocks with decent dividends.

GHARIB: A lot of people are wondering that in this climate, what do you think is going to be the new investment opportunity available to all of us in 2013? That's a question from Fay.

KANGAS: New investment opportunity.

GHARIB: What is your prediction?

KANGAS: They'll come up with something new just like ETF exchange- traded funds were relatively new a few years ago and now have gained such popularity it is almost, it's staggering how much money has gone into ETFs.

HUDSON: You mentioned how volatility could have the Dow see 8,000 and 18,000, maybe in the same year. Frank sent us a tweet on Twitter asking individual investors are afraid of the markets. What needs to be done to gain their confidence?

KANGAS: Less regulation. I think that investors are afraid that they make an investment and something comes along, the rules change from what got them into the investment in the first place. Well you can't change, you know, canoes in the middle of a stream.

GHARIB: On this whole subject of investor confidence, we do have a question from Billy who says what's the greatest changes that you've seen in the market today? You've had some perspective three years being away from it on a day-to-day basis. What do you see as the biggest change?

KANGAS: Well, Billy, I'll tell you that the computer is a wonderful thing, but it's not the greatest thing for investing. And for investors who don't have a high speed capability and have large box of stock at their arm's length. I think that that is -- it's taken away the idea that long- term, long-term investing is a good thing. I think that's one of the changes that I don't like. Too much computer meddling.

HUDSON: Well, Paul, as much as the markets have changed, you haven't. It's great to see and hear from you again. Susie, we have to say good night but I think it's only proper to ask Paul.

KANGAS: I'm Paul Kangas, wishing all of you the best of good buys.

END

urn:contentItem:5JDH-S3M1-DY0W-42TN-00000-00Nightly Business Report2013-02-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:43ZLexisNexisNightly Business ReportLanhamFULL TEXT

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Good evening. I'm Tom Hudson. Stocks fall on fresh signs that even the Federal Reserve is not sure how much is enough when it comes to boosting the economy, by buying government bonds.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Good evening. I'm Susie Gharib. Can two weaklings become strong by teaming up? That's what Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) and Office Max are hoping for, as they decide to merge.

HUDSON: And a bit of a mixed picture on American housing, contractors break ground on more single family homes, but pull back on building apartments and condos.

GHARIB: We have that and more tonight on NBR. How much longer should the Federal Reserve continue to stimulate the economy? That question was intensely debated at the central bank's policy meeting in January according to the minutes that were released today. Stocks sold off on that news, as investors worry the Fed might taper off its stimulus program sooner than expected and before its goal of seeing a big pick up in the job market.

Now the Fed has been buying $85 billion of mortgage-backed securities and Treasuries every month to pump up the economy. Here's what those Fed minutes revealed. Many policymakers voiced concerns about potential costs and risks from more bond buying. Others said that the easy money policies might encourage excessive risk-taking and that could have adverse consequences for financial stability. Policymakers also noted positive developments in the economy, as more businesses are optimistic about the economic outlook. But nervousness about the Fed's next moves pulled down stocks. On Wall Street the Dow lost 108 points, closing below the critical 14,000 level. The NASDAQ was down about 50, the S&P lost 19 points.

HUDSON: Before the Federal Reserve's notes on its last meeting were released this afternoon, we saw a mixed report this morning on the American housing market. Construction starts on new homes fell 8.5 percent in January. But that drop in the headline number was pulled down by a drop in apartment and condominium construction. The number of single family homes that began going up last month rose 0.8 of a percent up to its highest level since the great recession. Darren Gersh digs deeper.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: In housing, one month does not a trend make. Analysts shrugged off the news that housing starts fell last month. Instead they're looking to encouraging trends on home prices, rents and overall demand.

JED SMITH, MANAGING DIR., NATL ASSN. OF REALTORS: There are going to be these squiggles, blips in the market as things happen, just because they happen from month to month -- snow storms, weather, holidays, whatever, but right now we are in a recovering market.

GERSH: Homes sales are up more than 10 percent over last year and builders are picking up the pace. They are now on track to build around 900,000 homes this year, but by the end of the year, the National Association of Realtors expects the pace to pick up to an annual rate of 1.1 million starts. That's great, but keep in mind a normal year for home construction is closer to 1.8 million. The outlook for apartments and other multi-family construction is also good, even though those starts dropped last month. Rents rose 4.5 percent last year and researchers at Zillow expect a similar increase this year. That's why investors are pouring into the market and building new apartments.

STAN HUMPHRIES, CHIEF ECONOMIST, ZILLOW: Assuming you can buy the property cheaply or build it cheaply and you can rent it out, then you're seeing 4.5 percent growth in your top line numbers for what you are able to rent it out for looks pretty attractive.

GERSH: But the outlook varies depending on where you live and how strong the job market is in your area.

SMITH: The market will be up a lot more in Texas than it will be in parts of the east coast. Of course, on the west coast we've got a bit of a housing shortage. Inventory is tightest there. So I think there we will continue to see starts and see more starts in the future, simply because we've got tight inventory.

GERSH: Economists say housing is far from normal but it is now strong enough that it's once again playing its traditional supporting role for the economy following a tough recession. Darren Gersh, NBR, Washington.

GHARIB: Joe Davis joins us now. He's chief economist at Vanguard. That's the giant mutual fund company. Joe, nice to have you with us on this important day. Let me start by asking you, do you think the Fed is taking on too much risk?

JOE DAVIS, CHIEF ECONOMIST, VANGUARD GROUP: I think there is an argument that can be made. We've had a concern for more than a year that there are both costs as well as benefits with respect to very aggressive monetary policy. And just some of the behavior we've seen in the financial markets. I know the earlier report talked about excessive risk taking. So I've had a concern that those costs associated with monetary policy may not have been given the sort of credence they should have been. So a positive development in my mind, to today's minutes was that Federal Reserve policymakers were more aggressively talking about both the pros and cons with respect to aggressive monetary policy.

GHARIB: One thing that we've been hearing repeatedly from the Federal Reserve is that they're not going to make any change in this policy, raising interest rates or anything like that, until the economy is stronger. Most notably that the job market picks up, that the unemployment rate gets to the 6.5 percent level. So given today's numbers that we've had on housing and given that we're seeing that gasoline prices are going up, is the economy really strong enough to even begin talking about raising interest rates?

DAVIS: I don't know about that, but I think it is important to start talking about the beginning of the end in terms of how aggressively the Federal Reserve has purchased certain securities, particularly fixed-income securities. And so I think in that regard, I would make the case that the economy is markedly stronger today than it was just a year or two ago. You mentioned housing. The business sector, consumers are less debt-burdened than they were two or three years ago. And so by those measures, I'm hard- pressed to find the reason why six months from now, the Federal Reserve would have the pedal to the floor of the car so to speak as they have had for the past two or three years.

GHARIB: What is going to be the time table on this? To some extent, we saw with the gold prices today and oil prices that commodities are already responding to some changes in the marketplace. But when do you think that the Fed realistically will be acting on an exit strategy?

DAVIS: I think the exit strategy will be over the next six to 12 months in terms of more vocal conversations and guidance with respect to the amount and the frequency of their purchases. I think a later stage is then contemplation of raising interest rates, raising the Fed funds rate, which is effectively at zero. I think there it will be much more important on the labor market front in terms of job progress. I think all the other conditions are in place to see a modest acceleration in job growth, but it is going to take some time to bring that unemployment rate down, if I'm correct, that some Americans return to the labor force.

GHARIB: One concern for a lot of people as investors is what do I do now? A lot of people started putting money in the market. I know you're an economist, but you also are at Vanguard with all of the mutual funds. What is the view at Vanguard about what investors should be doing right now, given the uncertainty about this and things going on in Washington?

DAVIS: I think the hardest thing to do but I think what many investors actually are doing is to actually look through some of these headlines, to embrace that long-term orientation, look at the balance and risks and what you're trying to achieve with your portfolio. And if that ascertation (ph) of that plan is the same today as it was two, five, 10 years ago, it is really critical to stick with that plan. I think even going back three years ago, our message to clients was, listen, the economic environment may be challenging, but you can still have decent portfolio returns. And actually since that time, we've had decent portfolio returns, both on the equity market as well as in bond portfolios. So continuing to reaffirm that message and for investors to stay invested in markets. Because we are going to have ups and downs as the economy just muddles through some of this.

GHARIB: A lot more to talk about and we'll continue this conversation, but we have to wrap it up for now. Thanks so much, Joe Davis, chief economist at Vanguard.

DAVIS: Thank you, Susie.

RUBEN RAMIREZ, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Still ahead, Martha's in the middle of a courtroom showdown between two major retailers. What's at stake for the stores and her brand?

HUDSON: There is progress to report tonight from Boeing (NYSE:BA) on the battery issue plaguing its 787 Dreamliner. Still the planes remain grounded this evening. The aircraft maker may have found a fix for the plane's battery problems, by making bigger gaps between battery cells, that's according to Reuters. Boeing's head of commercial engines is expected to meet with the head of the Federal Aviation Administration Friday to present a 10-point plan to prevent battery fires or meltdowns. Neither Boeing (NYSE:BA) nor the FAA are commenting. Boeing (NYSE:BA) shares rose slightly today to close at $74.78 per share.

GHARIB: Two big and struggling office supply companies are teaming up. Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) is merging with Office Max in a stock deal valued at more than $1 billion. A union of the two companies has been rumored for years, given trouble in the office supply sector. But investors didn't buy in to the concept. Shares of Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) tumbled 16 percent; Office Max fell 7 percent and even rival Staples (NASDAQ:SPLS) was down today on the news, off 7 percent. Erika Miller reports.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: If you want a good read on the economy, it helps to watch demand for office supplies. When the economy is booming, businesses need more pens, paper and printers. But growth has been weak since the great recession and that has meant less demand for office products. Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) and Office Max have been struggling behind industry leader Staples (NASDAQ:SPLS).

LIANG FENG, SPECIALTY RETAIL ANALYST, MORNINGSTAR: Staples (NASDAQ:SPLS) is just -- their retail store is about 25-30 percent more productive than comparable locations. And they also have much more attractive business customer mix. They have the mid-size customers, compared to Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) and Office Max which are dependent on the lower margin large customers.

MILLER: Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) and Office Max hope by merging, they will be able to save big bucks by closing stores, combining operations, cutting advertising costs and negotiating better prices from suppliers. But office supply stores are also facing stiff competition from Wal-Mart (NYSE:WMT), Costco (NASDAQ:COST) and Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN). Those retailers have lower cost structures which often means lower prices. What's worse, the office supply stores are losing their most lucrative customers.

FENG: Your highest margin customers are your small business customers or somebody who just wants to buy something for the home office. And what we've seen is that Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) and Costco (NASDAQ:COST) are targeting these higher margin small business customers.

MILLER: Those struggles are reflected in the Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) and Office Max stock prices. Shares of both companies have plunged more than 70 percent from their highs back in 2006 and 2007, respectively. Staples (NASDAQ:SPLS) and Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) tried to merge in 1997, but the deal was blocked by regulators because of fear it would lead to higher prices. But most industry experts give this deal a high probability of going through. Longer-term, this deal is expected to be good for Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) and Office Max, but also their biggest competitor. If Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) and Office Max close stores, Staples (NASDAQ:SPLS) will face competition. Erika Miller, NBR, New York.

HUDSON: Combined these two companies have about 2,000 retail stores in North America. And as Erika just mentioned, some of those stores are expected to close, if the deal happens. That potentially could leave vacant millions of square feet of commercial real estate. Brian Jones is a portfolio manager for the Neuberger Berman real estate fund. He joins us tonight from the NASDAQ. Brian, what kind of shape is retail real estate in as it faces what could be a pretty big consolidation?

BRIAN JONES, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, NEUBERGER BERMAN REAL ESTATE FUND: Well, thank you for having me tonight. I think retail real estate is in a very good situation right now. What we've seen over the past two years have been improving occupancies and in many of the better markets, we're beginning to see rental rate growth. This is largely driven by the fact that there is very little new construction of retail centers going on in the United States currently. And thus, any retailers looking to grow have to find space in the existing centers in order to fund and continue their growth efforts.

HUDSON: Let's assume that Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) and Office Max are successful in combining their resources. Does this square footage, presumably that would become vacant in the years ahead, actually help relieve some of the pressure that you're seeing today?

JONES: Well, what we would say is that these two tenants are still relatively small when compared to the total pie of retail real estate. When we looked at the REITs in our coverage universe, we found that combined, Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) and Office Max were in every case at less than 2 percent of the rental revenues for the REITs in our coverage universe. So together, they're relatively small tenants for the overall retail REIT universe and the retail space in general. What it will provide is the opportunity for some of the retailers that have growth plans to actually find centers to grow in. And so we think that over time, a lot of the stores that are closed will be released to stronger tenants. And in many cases, that will end up strengthening the underlying center, where the Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) or the Office Max have gone out.

HUDSON: You mentioned your coverage universe and you did bring along one kind of outdoor shopping real estate investment trust that you do like here, Federal reality investment trust, ticker on this one is FRT. What make this on stand out in a crowded market?

JONES: One thing I would like to point out is that this highlights one of the benefits of investing in REITs, as opposed to a single piece of direct real estate. Most of the retail REITs in our coverage universe own dozens, if not hundreds, of retail centers. So they're generally diversified by geography or by tenant mix and by product type. So Federal realty is an excellent example of a retail REIT that owns high quality centers in areas that have high population densities and above average incomes. And these are the locations where many of the growing retailers, such as TJ Max and Marshal's, Nordstrom (NYSE:JWN) Rack, Five Guys Burgers, Panera Bread (NASDAQ:PNRA) -- the retailers that are looking to grow are focused on these higher income, higher density markets. And this is where Federal is positioned. And we think that they are positioned to do well in the future.

HUDSON: OK.

JONES: Office Depot (NYSE:ODP) and Office Max are not within their top 25 tenants.

HUDSON: Gotcha. And that's something you like at this point for FRT. Do you have a position in the fund in that stock?

JONES: Yes, we do own Federal reality in our mutual funds, the Neuberger Berman real estate fund.

HUDSON: And you help manage it. It is Brian Jones along with us tonight from Neuberger Berman. Thanks Brian.

JONES: Thank you.

GHARIB: It's Macy's (NYSE:M) versus JC Penney in a high stakes fight over bed linens, cocktail napkins and kitchen tools. At issue here, who will be allowed to carry products with Martha Stewart's name on them? Macy's (NYSE:M) has been selling Stewart's merchandise since 2007. It claims it owns the exclusive rights to carry her home furnishings. But rival JC Penney argues it has the right to sell other Stewart-branded products that Macy's (NYSE:M) doesn't carry. Ruben Ramirez reports.

RAMIREZ: Martha's in the middle, as two of the nation's best-known department stores fight in New York State Supreme Court over just who can carry the domestic diva's home products.

GREG LITTLE, PARTNER, WHITE & CASE: Two different companies are looking at the same agreement and are interpreting it different ways. Macys is interpreting it very broadly; Penney's is interpreting it very narrowly.

RAMIREZ: There's no denying the appeal of carrying Martha Stewart's brand. Macy's (NYSE:M) says it has billions of dollars on the line.

MICHAEL APPEL, FOUNDER, APPEL & ASSOCIATES: For Macys, having a differentiated exclusive brand is critical to their competitive strategy and they've invested a lot of time and effort in building up the Martha Stewart brand, giving her exposure in the stores and it's a linchpin of their home strategy.

RAMIREZ: For, JCP, Martha is a key part of its store within a store turnaround plan.

APPEL: She can appeal to the kind of customer that Penney's has and the customer whom they want to get which is more I think a little more upscale than what they have right now.

RAMIREZ: Penney's is counting on a clause in Stewart's original contract with Macy's (NYSE:M), which allowed her to open stand-alone stores, arguing the clause never said that stand alone shops could not be inside a bigger store. If JCP is successful, Appel says it opens up another retail channel for Stewart's company.

APPEL: The merchandising end of her business is the only part of her business right now that is growing and is profitable and for her to be able to increase her distribution is critical to her business strategy.

RAMIREZ: The trial got underway in a Manhattan Federal courtroom today and now that it's begun, attorneys say a settlement could be coming.

LITTLE: There is something about a trial that forces parties to look at the facts a little bit differently than they do when they're not at trial and it may well be that they reach a compromise at that point.

RAMIREZ: Martha Stewart, along and the CEOs of both Macy's (NYSE:M) and JC Penney are expected to take the stand. The trial is slated to last about two-and-a-half weeks. But unlike other courtroom cases which are decided by a jury, one judge will decide the outcome of this one. Ruben Ramirez, NBR, New York.

HUDSON: In the "Market Focus" here today, what started out as just some mild selling picked up this afternoon with some Federal Reserve officials worrying about how long to keep buying bonds to help the economy. Here's the daily trade for the S&P 500. Now the news from the Federal Reserve came out just after 2:00 Eastern time. That's when the index starting seeing some selling momentum. The index finished down by 1.2 percent. Remember though, it was at a five and a half year high at yesterday's close. Trading volume though did pick up, 815 million shares moving on the big board, two billion traded on the NASDAQ.

All 10 of the major stock sectors were lower today. The materials sector seeing the biggest loss, down 2.8 percent followed by the selling that we saw in energy and consumer discretionary sectors.

Two gold and copper miners saw the heaviest selling among those material stocks. Gold and copper metal prices were down sharply today. Freeport McMoran falling 6 percent. This is a two-and-a-half month low for FCX. Newmont Mining (NYSE:NEM) falling 5.5 percent, NEM tonight at a new 52-week low. AA, aluminum maker Alcoa (NYSE:AA) hit too, falling 3.3 percent. Alcoa (NYSE:AA) has been seeing aluminum prices stabilize.

In addition to the drop in new home construction last month, we heard from home builder Toll Brothers (NYSE:TOL). It earned $0.03 per share in the last quarter, certainly an improvement from the loss a year ago, but considerably less than estimates. The company reported that average selling prices were lower. Shares were lower as well, falling 9 percent. The stock has lost 10 percent in less than a week after staging a big rally over the past year. Other homebuilder stocks getting hit. Pulte Group falling 6.8 percent, DR Horton off by 5.8 percent.

Foxconn is not a household name in the U.S., but if you use an Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhone, Hewlett-Packard (NYSE:HPQ) computer or many other dozens of other electronic devices, Foxconn is the Taiwanese company that assembles it. Today Foxconn said it has frozen the hiring of assembly line workers in China after the lunar holiday there. That fed speculation about demand for Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) and HP products. Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) shares falling 2.2 percent since the plant affected makes iPhone fives, but Foxconn said its decision is not related to making the iPhone. An analyst at investment banking firm UBS thinks it could be instead because of less demand for Hewlett-Packard (NYSE:HPQ) desktop computers. HPQ shares down by 1.1 percent. HPs quarterly earnings are due tomorrow after the closing bell, one to watch.

Independent energy companies Devon and Anadarko updated their shareholders on their latest strategies. Both though were greeted today with selling. APC is Anadarko Petroleum (NYSE:APC), down 4.5 percent. Its energy production outlook was less than expected while its forecast for capital spending was more than anticipated. Anadarko says it expects to be among the most active deepwater drillers this year. Devon Energy (NYSE:DVN) falling 6.6 percent after saying it may try again to spin off its pipeline and processing businesses. It tried that six years ago, but stopped after the economy weakened.

Four of the five most actively traded exchange-traded products were lower on the broad market sell-off. The S&P 500 volatility note though jumped 8.6 percent. It usually moves in the opposite direction of the broad market as it did today. And that is tonight's "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Whether it's Facebook (NASDAQ:FB), Instagram or Pinterest, there always seems to be a hot start-up in the tech pipeline. But as tonight's commentator explains, the next big tech company might not be as original as you think. He's Harry Lin, executive-in-residence at Idealab. It's a technology incubator in Pasadena, California.

HARRY LIN, EXECUTIVE-IN-RESIDENCE, IDEALAB: An irony in the world of technology start-ups is that we tend to copy each other a lot. I call this ironic because the image of tech start-ups is that they're all about innovation and risk taking. Yet, venture capital investors and tech entrepreneurs all know that for every Instagram that gets launched, there are at least 10 other start-ups that pretty much are Instagram, just with a different name. Did you know that there are at least three well-funded startups? I'm talking more than $10 million of investor capital, that match dog owners with dog sitters? The number of me-too start-ups goes crazy when you look at other types of products and services: project management software, call ordering food online, music streaming, cloud file storage and I can't even keep track of all the fashion and clothing sale sites duking it out on the Internet. There are scores of them! Even Pinterest has at least half a dozen straight up clones.

So why is an industry that's supposedly about innovation and disruption so quick to copy itself? Investors may call their capital venture, but they're looking for safe bets. So when something seems to be working, why not invest in the same thing? We also know that in some niches, there's space for several winners, so maybe investing in the me-too will work out. The entrepreneurial myth is that we invent new stuff, when, much of the time, we engineer twists or slants on old stuff. It's really, really hard to come up with a brand-new idea that's never been tried. So this copy-catting will continue and I'll continue to call it ironic. I'm Harry Lin.

HUDSON: Whether copy cats or not, all entrepreneurs certainly face difficulty at one time or another staying motivated. Our NBRU partners at Vanderbilt University have eight steps for staying motivated to reach long- term goals. Just head to nbr.com and look for that NBRU tab.

GHARIB: And let's take a look at what's coming up tomorrow on NBR. Ford is hiring. It's adding jobs at its Cleveland plant that builds the eco-boost engines. But it's not alone. We look at job creation in the U.S. auto industry.

HUDSON: That's it for the broadcast here on NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Wednesday night, February 20. Have a great evening, you too Susie.

GHARIB: Same to you Tom. Thanks for watching everyone and we'll see you right back here tomorrow night.

END
